B.  Plans, specifications and estimates of the work to be done; provided however, that where the proposed project is to be carried out in cooperation with any other governmental agency, the city engineer may adopt the plans, specifications, and estimates of such agency; 
C.  An estimate of the probable cost of the improvement, including any legal, administrative and engineering costs attributable thereto; 
D.  An estimate of the unit cost of the improvement to the specially benefited properties; 
E.  A recommendation as to the method of assessment to be used to arrive at a fair apportionment of the whole or any portion of the cost of the improvement to the properties specially benefited; 
F.  The description and assessed value of each lot, parcel of land, or portion thereof, to be specially benefited by the improvement, with the names of the contract purchasers thereof; 
G.  A statement of outstanding assessments against property to be assessed. 
(Ord. 762 § 1, 1967) 
3.12.030 - Council's action on report. 
    After the city engineer's report shall have been filed with the city recorder, the council may thereafter by motion: 
A.  Approve the report; 
B.  Modify the report and approve it as modified; 
C.  Require the city engineer to supply additional or different information for such improvement; or 
D.  Abandon the improvement. 
(Ord. 762 § 2, 1967) 
3.12.040 - Resolution and notice of hearing. 
    After the council shall have approved the city engineer's report as submitted or modified, the council shall, by resolution, declare its intention to make such improvement, provide the manner and method of carrying out the improvement, and shall direct the city recorder to give notice of such improvement by two publications one week apart in a newspaper of general circulation within the city and by mailing copies of such notice by registered or certified mail to the owners to be assessed for the costs of such improvement, which notice shall contain the following items: 
A.  A statement that the retort of the city engineer is on file in the office of the city recorder and is subject to public examination and that the report is by reference thereto made a part of the notice; 
B.  A statement that the council will hold a public hearing on the proposed improvement on a specified date, which shall not be earlier than ten (10) days following the first publication of notice, at which objections and remonstrances to such improvement will be heard by the council, and that if prior to such hearing there shall be presented to the city recorder valid, written remonstrances of the owners of two-thirds of the property to be specially assessed for such improvement, then the improvement will be abandoned for at least six months, unless the proposed public improvement is a sidewalk or an improvement unanimously declared by the council to be needed at once because of an emergency; 
C.  A description of the real property to be specially benefited by the improvement; and such description may be made as specified in ORS 223.387 or by a description of the boundaries or the area or district to be assessed; 
D.  The names of the owners of such property; 
E.  The estimate of the unit cost of the improvement to the property specially benefited by a statement of such cost set opposite the name of the owner thereof; 
F.  The total cost of the improvement to be paid by special assessments to benefited properties. 
(Ord. 929 § 2, 1976: Ord. 762 § 3, 1967) 
3.12.050 - Manner of doing work. 
    The council may provide in the improvement resolution that the construction work may be done in whole, or in part, by a private contractor, by the city, by any other governmental agency, or by any combination thereof. 
(Ord. 762 § 4, 1967) 
3.12.060 - Hearing. 
    At the time of the public hearing on the proposed improvement, the council shall receive all written remonstrances and oral objections. If written remonstrances shall have been received prior to the hearing from the owners of two-thirds of the property to be specially assessed for such improvement, action shall be suspended for six months; except that if the improvement shall be a sidewalk, or if the council shall unanimously declare the improvement to be needed at once because of an emergency, then the council may proceed with the improvement. The council may, by motion, at the time of the hearing, after hearing written remonstrances and oral objections, if any, order the improvement to be carried out in accordance with the resolution, or the council may, on its own motion, abandon the improvement. 
(Ord. 762 § 5, 1967) 
3.12.070 - Call for bids. 
    The council may, in its discretion, direct the city recorder to advertise for bids for construction of all, or any part, of the improvement project on the basis of the council-approved city engineer's report and before the passage of the resolution, or after the passage of the resolution and before the public hearing on the proposed improvement, or at any time after the public hearing. However, no contract shall be let until after the public hearing has been held to hear remonstrances and oral objections to the proposed improvement. In the event that any part of the work of the improvement is to be done under contract bids, then the council shall determine the time and manner of advertisement for bids, and the contracts shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder; provided, that the council shall have the right to reject all bids when they are deemed unreasonable or unsatisfactory. The city shall provide for the bonding of all contractors for the faithful performance of any contract let under its authority, and the provisions thereof in case of default shall be enforced by action in the name of the city. 
    If the council finds, upon opening bids for the work of such improvement, that the lowest responsible bid is substantially in excess of the city engineer's estimate, it may, in its discretion, provide for holding a special hearing of objections to the proceeding with the improvement on the basis of such bid, and it may direct the city recorder to publish one notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. 762 § 6, 1967) 
3.12.080 - Assessment. 
A.  Proposed Assessment. After the aforesaid hearing, and after the council has moved to proceed with the improvement, and after the council has apportioned the cost of the improvement (or so much thereof that is to be assessed to the property benefited) upon the property specially benefited by the improvement, the city recorder shall within thirty (30) days prior to the hearing thereon give notice of such proposed assessment by publication thereof in the newspaper, Coquille Valley Sentinel, once each week for two consecutive weeks, making a total of two publications only; such notice to contain the following: 
1.  The specification of the improvement that may be by name only; 
2.  A statement that the proposed assessment is on file in the office of the city recorder; 
3.  The name of the owner of such property; 
4.  A description in accordance with ORS 223.387 of the real property to be assessed or by description of the boundaries of the area or district to be assessed; 
5.  That objection to such assessment may be made in writing, stating the grounds of the objection to the council, and filed with the city recorder prior to the commencement of the meeting of the council at which the assessment is to be considered; 
6.  The time and place of the meeting of the council whereat the. passage of an ordinance assessing the cost of the improvement will be considered. The city recorder shall also mail a copy of such notice, postage prepaid, to such owner. If the address of the owner or owner's agent is unknown, he or she shall mail the notice addressed to the owner or agent at Coquille, Oregon. 
B.  Hearing. At the time specified in the notice or at such subsequent time as the council may fix, the council shall consider the proposed assessments and all objections made thereto, and shall have power, at its discretion and without any further notice, to consider, ascertain and determine the amount to which each lot or part of lot or parts of lands so assessed is benefited by reason of the improvement. The council shall then declare the assessment by ordinance and direct the city recorder to enter a statement thereof in the Docket of City Liens. 
(Ord. 929 § 1, 1976: Ord. 762 § 7, 1967) 
3.12.090 - Method of assessment and alternative methods of financing. 
    The council in adopting a method of assessment of the costs of the improvement may: 
A.  Use any just and reasonable method of determining the extent of any improvement district consistent with the benefits derived; 
B.  Use any method of apportioning the sum to be assessed as is just and reasonable between the properties determined to be specially benefited; 
C.  Authorize payment by the city of all, or any part of the cost of any such improvement when in the opinion of the council the topographical or physical conditions, or unusual or excessive public travel, or other character of the work involved warrants only a partial payment or no payment by the benefited property of the costs of the improvement. 
    Nothing contained in this chapter shall preclude the council from using any other available means of financing improvements, including federal or state grants-in-aid, sewer charges or fees, revenue bonds, general obligation bonds, or any other legal means of finance. In the event that such other means of financing improvements are used, the council may, in its discretion, levy special assessments according to the benefits derived to cover any remaining part of the costs of the improvement. 
(Ord. 762 § 8, 1967) 
3.12.100 - Remedies. 
    Subject to the curative provisions of Section 3.12.170 and the rights of the city to reassess as provided in Section 3.12.180, all proceedings for writs of review and suits in equity may be filed not earlier than thirty (30) days nor later than sixty (60) days after the filing of written objections as provided herein. 
    If notice of the improvement shall not have been sent to the property owner, and if such owner did not otherwise have actual knowledge of the proposed improvement prior to the hearing thereon, he may file written objections with the city recorder alleging lack of jurisdiction, and any other objection he might have, all to be done within thirty (30) days after receiving notice or actual knowledge of the improvement. 
    All proceedings for writs of review and suits in equity shall be founded upon written objections duly and regularly made and filed by the property owner. 
    Such written objections of the property owner may be informal in nature, but shall specifically set forth every objection and the facts in support thereof with sufficient clarity to put the council to a consideration thereof. 
    No provision of this section shall be construed to lengthen any period of redemption or to affect the running of any statute of limitation. Any proceeding on a writ of review or suit in equity shall be abated if proceedings are commenced and diligently pursued by the city council to remedy or cure the alleged errors or defects. 
(Ord. 762 § 9, 1967) 
3.12.110 - Notice of assessment. 
    Within ten (10) days after the ordinance levying assessments has been passed, the city recorder shall send by registered or certified mail a notice of assessment to the owner of the assessed property, and shall publish notice of such assessment twice in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, the first publication of which shall be made not later than ten (10) days after the date of the assessment ordinance. The notice of assessment shall recite the date of the assessment ordinance and shall state that upon the failure of the owner of the property assessed to make application to pay the assessment in installments within ten (10) days from the date of the first publication of notice, or upon the failure of the owner to pay the assessment in full within 30 days from the date of the assessment ordinance, then interest will commence to run on the assessment and that the property assessed will be subject to foreclosure; and the notice shall further set forth a description of the property assessed, the name of the owner of the property, and the amount of each assessment. 
(Ord. 762 § 10, 1967) 
3.12.120 - Lien records and foreclosure proceedings. 
    After passage of the assessment ordinance by the council, the city recorder shall enter in the docket of city liens a statement as provided by Ordinance No. 798. Upon entry in the lien docket, the amount entered shall become a lien and charge upon the respective lots, parcels of land, or portions thereof, which have been assessed for the improvement. 
(Ord. 1155, 1983: Ord. 1093, 1981: Ord. 762 § 11, 1967) 
3.12.130 - Errors in assessment calculations. 
    Claimed errors in the calculation of assessments shall be called to the attention of the city recorder, who shall determine whether there has been an error in fact. If the recorder shall find that there has been an error in fact, he or she shall recommend to the council an amendment to the assessment ordinance to correct such error, and upon enactment of such amendment, the city recorder shall make the necessary correction in the docket of city liens and send a corrected notice of assessment by registered or certified mail. 
(Ord. 762 § 12, 1967) 
3.12.140 - Deficit assessment. 
    In the event that an assessment shall be made before the total cost of the improvement is ascertained, and if it is found that the amount of the assessment is insufficient to defray the expenses of the improvement, the council may, by motion, declare such deficit and prepare a proposed deficit assessment. The council shall set a time for a hearing of objections to such deficit assessment and shall direct the city recorder to publish one notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, and mail copies of such notice by registered or certified mail to the owners of property to be assessed for the costs of the improvement. After such hearing, the council shall make a just and equitable deficit assessment by ordinance which shall be entered in the docket of city liens as provided by this ordinance, and notices of the deficit assessment shall be published and mailed and the collection of the assessment shall be made in accordance with Sections 3.12.110 and 3.12.120. 
(Ord. 947, 1976: Ord. 762 § 13, 1967) 
3.12.150 - Rebates. 
    If, upon the completion of the improvement project, it is found that the assessment previously levied upon any property is more than sufficient to pay the costs of such improvements, then the council must ascertain and declare the same by ordinance, and when so declared, the excess amounts must be entered one lien docket as a credit upon the appropriate assessment. In the event that any assessment has been paid, the person who paid the same, or his or her legal representative, shall be entitled to the repayment of such rebate credit, or the portion thereof which exceeds the amount unpaid on the original assessment. 
(Ord. 762 § 14, 1967) 
3.12.160 - Abandonment of proceedings. 
    The council shall have full power and authority to abandon and rescind proceedings for improvements made under this chapter at any time prior to the final completion of such improvements; and if liens have been assessed upon any property under such procedure, they shall be cancelled, and any payments made on such assessments shall be refunded to the persons paying the same, their assigns or legal representatives. 
(Ord. 762 § 15, 1967) 
3.12.170 - Curative provisions. 
    No improvement assessment shall be rendered invalid by reason of a failure of the city engineer's report to contain all of the information required by Section 3.12.020, or by reason of a failure to have all of the information required to be in the improvement resolution, the assessment ordinance, the lien docket, or notices required to be published and mailed, nor by the failure to list the name of, or mail notice to, the owner of any property as required by this chapter, or by reason of any other error, mistake, delay, omission, irregularity, or other act, jurisdictional or otherwise, in any of the proceedings or steps herein specified, unless it appears that the assessment is unfair or unjust in its effect upon the person complaining; and the council shall have the power and authority to remedy and correct all such matters by suitable action and proceedings. 
(Ord. 762 § 16, 1967) 
3.12.180 - Reassessment. 
    Whenever any assessment, deficit or reassessment for any improvement which has been made by the city has been, or shall be, set aside, annulled, declared or rendered void, or its enforcement restrained by any court of this state, or any federal court having jurisdiction thereof, or when the council shall be in doubt as to the validity of such assessment, deficit assessment, or reassessment, or any part thereof, then the council may make a reassessment in the matter provided by the laws of the state of Oregon. 
(Ord. 762 § 17, 1967) 
3.12.190 - Publications. 
    The provisions of Sections 3.12.040 and 3.12.110 requiring publication of the description of real property affected by the improvement and property to be assessed may be made by describing such real property by Coos County, Oregon, tax lot number only, thereby avoiding description by metes and bounds or by lot and block, when deemed advisable by the city recorder. 
(Ord. 773, 1967: Ord. 762 § 19, 1967) 
3.12.200 - Period of time to pay assessments. 
    Pursuant to ORS 223.215, property owners whose real property has been assessed for an "improvement" as defined in ORS Chapter 223, providing for assessments for local improvements and methods of enforcing liens and in collecting assessments and financing improvements in cities. (Bancroft Bonding Act), shall have a period not to exceed ten (10) years to pay assessments in equal semi-annual installment payments as provided in said Section 223.215. 
(Ord. 910 § 1, 1975) 
Chapter 3.16 - LIEN SEARCHES 

3.16.010 - Authority. 
    The recorder of the city of authorized and directed to make searches of the lien records of the city and to issue certificates concerning the existence of liens upon property within the city after receiving applications for such certificates and the fees provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. 881 § 1, 1973) 
3.16.020 - Certificate contents. 
    The certificate of lien search authorized by this chapter shall contain a description of the property involved; shall set forth any liens that may be recorded in the lien records of the city on the date that such certificate is issued; and shall be directed and issued to the applicants for such certificate. 
(Ord. 881 § 2, 1973) 
3.16.040 - Separate certificates required for each parcel. 
    The city recorder shall issue a separate certificate and shall collect a separate fee for each distinct and contiguous parcel of land for which an application for certificate is made. 
(Ord. 881 § 4, 1973) 
3.16.050 - Liability for errors in certificate. 
    No person, firm or corporation, other than the party to whom a certificate shall be directed and issued, shall be entitled to rely upon any information contained in a certificate of lien of the city; and the city shall assume no responsibility and shall have no liability to any third person as a result of issuing any certificate of lien. There shall be no liability for an error in certificate in excess of the actual loss to the party to whom a certificate has been issued, and such damages shall in no event exceed the amount of the omitted lien or liens existing upon the property in question on the date of the issuance of the certificate. There shall also be no liability where any of the persons to whom a certificate has been issued has knowledge or notice of the lien or has suffered a loss through their own neglect or carelessness. In any case where the city shall be liable for damages in the issuance of a certificate of lien search, it shall, upon payment of such damage, become subrogated to all of the rights of the damaged party and shall be entitled to an assignment of such rights against any and all third parties who may be liable for such damage. 
(Ord. 881 § 5, 1973) 
3.16.060 - Indemnity limit. 
    In no case shall the indemnity provided in Section 3.16.050 exceed the amount of the indemnity reserve fund described in Section 3.16.030. 
(Ord. 881 § 6, 1973) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - REGISTRATION OF BUSINESSES 

5.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Business" means and includes any trade, profession or occupation conducted in the city. 
    "Person" means and includes any person, firm, partnership, association, joint venture, syndicate, society or domestic or foreign corporation. 
(Ord. 1276 § 1, 1990) 
5.04.020 - Business-Registration requirement. 
    Any person engaged in business in the city, who has a business address or business located in the city, is required to register the business with the city at least five days prior to the commencement of operation of the business in the city. 
(Ord. 1276 § 2, 1990) 
5.04.030 - Business registration information. 
    Upon a form provided by the city, any person registering a business to be conducted in the city shall provide the following information: 
A.  Name, address and telephone number of owner. If the owner of the business is a corporation, the corporation; 
B.  The primary nature of the trade or operation of the business enterprise; 
C.  If products will be offered for retail sale, a description of the primary nature of the goods or wares for sale; 
D.  The location from which the business will operate; 
E.  The business hours, if any. 
(Ord. 1276 § 3, 1990) 
5.04.040 - Business registration record. 
    Upon receipt of business registration information as provided in Section 5.04.020, the city will maintain a record of businesses registered in the city in accordance with the information received on the business registration forms required. 
(Ord. 1276 § 4, 1990) 
5.04.050 - Nonlicense status. 
    A business registration filed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter does not constitute a license to conduct business in the city. The operation of any business enterprise in the city must be conducted in compliance with all state, federal and local laws, rules, regulations and ordinances. 
(Ord. 1276 § 5, 1990) 
5.04.060 - Registration fee. 
    A person filing a business registration form in accordance with the provisions of the ordinance shall submit therewith a registration fee of $-0- at the time of filing. 
(Ord. 1276 § 6, 1990) 
5.04.070 - Change in ownership or principal nature of business enterprise. 
    In the event of a change in ownership of the business being operated in the city or a change in the primary nature of the business, whether or not the business remains at the same location, a new business registration shall be filed in accordance with the provisions of Section 5.04.020 within five days of the change. 
(Ord. 1276 § 7, 1990) 
5.04.080 - Existing businesses exempt. 
    All businesses existing within the city as of the date of enactment of the ordinance codified in this chapter shall be exempt from the requirement of business registration as provided in this chapter, except that an existing business shall be required to comply with the terms of this chapter in the event of the occurrence of a change in ownership or a change in the primary nature of the business enterprise as required by Section 5.04.070. 
(Ord. 1276 § 8, 1990) 
5.04.090 - Violations-Penalties. 
    It is unlawful for any person to carry on or transact business as defined in this chapter without first complying with the registration requirements of this chapter. Any person who shall engage in or carry on a business within the corporate limits of the city without first having filed a business registration form as required by this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this chapter and shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine in an amount not in excess of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. 1276 § 9, 1990) 
Chapter 5.12 - GARAGE SALES 

5.12.010 - Garage sale defined. 
    "Garage sale" means the public sale of new or used goods within the city limits by an individual or a group of individuals from any private property, including but not limited to garages, porches, carports or yards, when the individual or group of individuals is not in the business of selling goods or not licensed as a second-hand dealer, or when the property from which such sale is to be conducted is not within a zone permitting commercial businesses or when the sale is not otherwise permitted under the provisions of this chapter or the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. 1180 § 1, 1984) 
5.12.020 - Limitation on the number of sales. 
    No individual or group of individuals shall hold or conduct more than two garage sales at any one location within the city limits located within a residential district in any one calendar year. No garage sale shall be conducted for a period longer than three consecutive days. 
(Ord. 1180 § 2, 1984) 
5.12.030 - Sirens. 
    In any residential district in the city where a garage sale is permitted under the terms of this chapter, there shall be only one sign posted on the premises advertising the sale. 
(Ord. 1180 § 3, 1984) 
5.12.040 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Violation of any provision of this chapter is punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day of the violation. 
(Ord. 1180 § 4, 1984) 
Chapter 5.16 - ITINERANT MERCHANTS 

5.16.010 - Purpose. 
    This chapter is intended to protect the public safety and welfare by regulating persons engaged in business as itinerant merchants. 
(Ord. 1346 § 1, 1993) 
5.16.020 - Itinerant merchant defined. 
A.  "Itinerant Merchant" means: 
1.  A person, individually or as principal, agent or employee of another, who goes from place to place or from house to house, carrying for sale and offering or exposing for sale goods, wares, merchandise or services to persons other than merchants; 
2.  A person, individually or as principal, agent or employee of another, who goes from place to place or from house to house, selling or offering to sell for future delivery, by sample or catalog, at retail, goods, wares, merchandise or services to persons who are not merchants; or 
3.  A person individually or as principal, agent or employee of another, who occupies a temporary fixed location, taking orders for future delivery or selling and delivering from stock on hand and doing business in much the same manner as a permanent business. 
B.  Itinerant merchant shall not include: 
1.  Any person who is acting solely as the owner, agent or employee of a wholesale business which regularly conducts business with local retail merchants within the city; 
2.  Any person who is acting solely as the owner, agent or employee of a business with a permanent business location or residence within the Coos County; or 
3.  A charitable, religious, patriotic or philanthropic organization desiring to solicit, or have solicited in its name, money, donations of money or property or financial assistance of any kind, or desiring to sell or distribute any item of literature or merchandise for which a fee is charged or solicited from person, other than members of such organization, on the streets, in office buildings, from house to house, or in public places, for a charitable, religious, patriotic or philanthropic, purpose. 
(Ord. 1346 § 2, 1993) 
5.16.030 - License required. 
    No person shall engage in business as an itinerant merchant as defined in Section 5.16.020 within the corporate limits of the city without first applying for and obtaining a license. 
(Ord. 1346 § 3, 1993) 
5.16.040 - License application. 
    An applicant for a license shall submit a sworn, written application on a form to be furnished by the city recorder. The application shall include the following information: 
A.  The applicant's true name, permanent address, and an address which the city may use for purposes of notifying the applicant; 
B.  The true name and address of the person appointed as agent for accepting service of process for the applicant; 
C.  The true name and address of a person for whom the applicant is acting as an employee or agent. If the applicant is acting as the agent of a corporation: 
1.  The address of the registered office of the corporation in Oregon, and 
2.  The name and address of the registered agent of the corporation in Oregon; 
D.  A description of the nature of the business operation the applicant will conduct; 
E.  A description of the goods, wares, merchandise or services the applicant will offer for sale; 
F.  The location from which the applicant will operate; 
G.  The length of time the applicant will conduct the business and the hours of operation; 
H.  The past business experience of the applicant; 
I.  Past criminal convictions involving unlawful trade practices as defined by ORS 646.608, fraud, or crimes involving moral turpitude; 
J.  Known consumer complaints made to local or state consumer agencies. 
(Ord. 1346 § 4, 1993) 
5.16.050 - Application and license fee. 
A.  The applicant shall submit with the completed application a nonrefundable fee to cover the cost of administration and investigation in the amount of sixty dollars ($60.00). 
B.  In addition to the administrative and investigative fee described in subsection A of this section, license fees shall be as follows: two dollars fifty cents ($2.50) per day, five dollars ($5.00) per month, ten dollars ($10.00) per year. Such fees shall be paid at the time of the issuance of the license. 
    The amount of the fee may be changed by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 1346 § 5, 1993) 
5.16.060 - Investigation and determination. 
A.  The city recorder shall refer an application to the chief of police for investigation to determine whether the public safety will be properly safeguarded. The investigation shall include the manner in which the applicant proposes to do business, examination of any vehicle or conveyance to be used in connection with the business, and inspection of the place from which the applicant proposes to do business. 
B.  The license and permit shall not be granted if: 
1.  The activity or devise to be licensed would not comply with city ordinances, or state or federal law. 
2.  The licensed activity or device would endanger property or the public health or safety. 
3.  Any false or misleading information is supplied in the application or any information requested is omitted from the application. 
4.  The applicant has been convicted of a crime involving unlawful trade practices as defined by ORS 646.608, fraud or moral turpitude within the last five years. 
5.  The applicant has been the subject of an unreasonable number of consumer complaints in the last five years. 
6.  The applicant has been the subject of an unlawful trade practices suit or investigation under ORS Chapter 646 which resulted in civil penalties assessed against him or her. 
7.  The applicant has failed to comply with any other applicable provision of this chapter relating to the proposed conduct of the business. 
C.  If, as a result of the investigation, the application appears to be satisfactory, the city recorder shall issue a license. 
D.  The city recorder shall keep a full record of all licenses issued. A license shall contain: 
1.  The number of the license; 
2.  The date of issue; 
3.  The nature of the business authorized; 
4.  The amount of the fee paid; 
5.  The expiration date; 
6.  The place of business; 
7.  The name or names of persons authorized to carry on the business. 
E.  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city recorder in regard to the denial of an application for license provided in this section shall have the right to appeal to the council of the city. Such appeal shall be taken by filing a written statement setting forth the grounds for the appeal with the council within ten (10) days after notice of the decision has been mailed by the city recorder to such person at his or her last known address. The council shall set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the licensee by mailing the notice to the licensee at his or her last known address at least ten (10) days prior to the date set for the hearing. The decision of the council on such appeal shall be final. 
(Ord. 1346 § 6, 1993) 
5.16.070 - Duration of license. 
A.  The license issued under this chapter shall be in effect for one year. 
B.  No itinerant merchant shall do business or leave any stand or structure associated with their business at the same location for more than six consecutive months and after six consecutive months has expired shall not reestablish their business or place any stand or structure associated with their business at that location for two consecutive months. If an itinerant merchant ceases to operate a business for fourteen (14) consecutive days, the license for that itinerant merchant shall automatically terminate and all stands, signs, storage facilities and structures of any kind associated with the business shall be immediately removed by an agent or employee of the city. 
(Ord. 1346 § 7, 1993) 
5.16.080 - Outside storage prohibited. 
    No outside storage or display of supplies, equipment, stock, wares or other materials associated with the itinerant merchant's business shall occur except while the itinerant merchant is present and open for business. 
(Ord. 1346 § 8, 1993) 
5.16.090 - Maintenance of premises. 
    The itinerant merchant's business premises and any adjacent areas used or under the control of the itinerant merchant shall at all times be kept neat, clean and free of debris. All stands, storage facilities or structures used shall be in good condition and well maintained. 
(Ord. 1346 § 9, 1993) 
5.16.100 - Exhibition of license. 
    The license issued under this chapter shall be worn conspicuously by the person or persons to whom the same shall be issued, on the lapel or other suitable place on the outer clothing, at all times while such person is engaged in the business for which such license is issued. 
(Ord. 1346 § 10, 1993) 
5.16.110 - Transfer of license. 
    No license issued under this chapter shall be transferable. 
(Ord. 1346 § 11, 1993) 
5.16.120 - Proof of insurance. 
A.  The applicant shall submit proof of general liability insurance coverage in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) to any one claimant for all claims arising out of a single accident or occurrence and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for any number of claims arising out of a single accident or occurrence. The applicant shall also submit proof of products liability and errors and omissions insurance coverage in the same amounts, if appropriate to the business proposed to be conducted. 
B.  The proof of insurance coverage required by this section may be satisfied by evidence that the applicant is an additional insured on an existing policy providing coverage in the required amounts. 
(Ord. 1346 § 12, 1993) 
5.16.130 - Appointment of agent for service of process. 
    Before any license herein provided shall be issued, the applicant shall submit with the application for the license an instrument, on the form provided by the city recorder, appointing a person who is a resident of the city as the applicant's true and lawful agent with full power and authority to accept process of service for and on behalf of the applicant with regard to any matters connected with or arising out of the business transacted under the license. The instrument shall contain the applicant's appointed agent's acknowledged consent to accept service, of process for the applicant. 
(Ord. 1346 § 13, 1993) 
5.16.140 - Loud noises and speaking devices. 
    No licensee under this chapter, nor anyone in his or her behalf, shall shout, make any outcry, blow a horn, ring a bell or use any other sound devise including loudspeakers, radio or amplifying systems upon any of the streets, alleys, parks or other public places of the city or upon any private premises in the city where sound of sufficient volume is emitted or produced therefrom capable of being plainly heard upon the streets, avenues, alleys or parks or other public places for the purpose of attracting attention to any goods, wares or merchandise which such licensee proposed to sell. 
(Ord. 1346 § 14, 1993) 
5.16.150 - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to inspect the itinerant merchant's place of business and the itinerant merchants in their respective territories to determine if this chapter has been or is being complied with and to enforce the provisions of this chapter against any person found in violation thereof. 
(Ord. 1346 § 15, 1993) 
5.16.160 - Conformance with other law. 
    Obtaining the license required by this chapter shall not exempt the licensee from other city ordinance requirements. 
(Ord. 1346 § 16, 1993) 
5.16.170 - License revocation. 
    The license issued under this chapter may be revoked by the common council of the city after notice of hearing for any of the following causes: 
A.  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
B.  Any fraud, misrepresentation, or false statements made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or merchandise; 
C.  Any violation of this chapter; 
D.  Conviction of the licensee for any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; 
E.  Conducting the business licensed under this chapter in an unlawful manner as to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare or the public. 
(Ord. 1346 § 17, 1993) 
5.16.180 - Stop order and notice of revocation. 
    If the city manager determines that there are probable grounds for revoking the itinerant merchant's license, he or she may take one of the following actions: 
1.  By written order, direct that the business operations be discontinued immediately pending a determination by the city council. The order shall specify the alleged grounds upon which the order is based and the date the council will act on the matter. No person shall continue to operate as an itinerant merchant after receiving a stop order from the city manager; or 
2.  Notify the licensee of the alleged violation and the date the council will consider the matter. The notice shall be given at least ten (10) days prior to the council meeting. 
3.  If a stop order is issued, the city manager shall submit the matter to the council for consideration at its next regularly scheduled council meeting. If a stop order is not issued, the city manager shall submit the matter to the council for consideration at its next available meeting. The decision of the council shall be final. 
(Ord. 1346 § 18, 1993) 
5.16.190 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, whether individually or as principal, agent or employee of another, violating any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day that a violation of this chapter continues constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1346 § 19, 1993) 
Chapter 5.20 - MOTOR VEHICLE WRECKING BUSINESSES 

5.20.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the term "business of wrecking motor vehicles" means the business of wrecking, dismantling, permanently disassembling, or substantially altering the form of any motor vehicle and/or any business required to be licensed by the state of Oregon under the provisions of ORS 822.100 to 822.150, as now constituted or hereafter amended. The term "building" means a structure or building which shall comply with the provisions of the building code of the city and which shall have, in addition to a roof completely covering the same, solid walls completely around all four sides thereof; provided, however, that such building may have the necessary windows, exits and doors, which shall be so constructed that the same may be completely closed. 
(Ord. 1301, 1991: Ord. 955, 1977: Ord. 5-264 § 1, 1948) 
5.20.020 - License required. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to carry on or conduct within the corporate limits of the city the business of wrecking motor vehicles unless and until he or she shall have received a license from the city authorizing the carrying on or conducting of such business as herein provided. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 2, 1948) 
5.20.030 - License fee. 
    Any person, persons, firm or corporation desiring to obtain a license for the purpose of conducting a business of wrecking motor vehicles within the corporate limits of the city shall pay the license fee therefor, which shall be the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year or any fraction of a year. Said license shall expire on December 31st next after the date of such license. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 3, 1948) 
5.20.040 - License not transferable. 
    A license granted under the provisions of this chapter shall not be assignable or transferable by the licensee and shall be effective for the place named in the application and for no other place or location. Upon the sale or transfer of the business conducted by any licensee under the provisions of this chapter, the purchaser thereof shall apply for and obtain a license to conduct a business. A person conducting a business under a license issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter desiring to move such business and to continue to conduct such business at some other location within the corporate limits of the city shall apply to the common council in writing for permission to move such business and any such move without such permission shall render void any license theretofore given to such licensee to so conduct the business. All applications made for licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall specify the name of the licensee and the location where the business is to be conducted. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 4, 1948) 
5.20.050 - Outside premises. 
    No motor vehicle parts belonging to or under the control of any person, firm or corporation conducting the business of wrecking motor vehicles within the corporate limits of the city, shall be placed or permitted to remain outside or near any building in which the business is conducted, and the person, firm or corporation conducting such business shall at all times keep the premises on the outside of the building clear and clean. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 5, 1948) 
5.20.060 - Parts left outside premises-Nuisance declared. 
    Any motor vehicle parts placed or left outside of a building on any premises where the business of wrecking motor vehicles is being conducted are declared to be a public nuisance, and the same may be abated summarily by the chief of police in addition to the imposition of any other penalty herein provided. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 6, 1948) 
5.20.070 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation conducting any motor vehicle wrecking business within the corporate limits of the city without having obtained a license therefor as required by this chapter, or any person who, having obtained such license, shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter upon conviction thereof before the city recorder, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), and thereupon any license theretofore granted to the person so convicted may be revoked at the pleasure of the common council. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 7, 1948) 
5.20.080 - Applicability. 
    None of the provisions of this chapter shall apply to or in any manner affect the right of any person not regularly engaged either as a primary occupation or as part-time employment, in the business of wrecking motor vehicles as herein defined, to dismantle or substantially alter the form of his or her own private motor vehicle on his or her own premises without obtaining a license herein required. 
(Ord. 5-264 § 8, 1948) 
Chapter 5.24 - SOCIAL GAMES AND GAMBLING 

5.24.010 - Gambling prohibited. 
    No person shall participate in, operate or assist in operating a gambling game or activity, including a lottery, except for the state lottery operated under the provisions of the Oregon Constitution. No person shall possess any property, instrument or device designated or adapted for use in any such gambling activity. Such property, instrument or device is a nuisance and may be summarily seized by a police officer. Seized property shall be placed in the custody of the chief of police. On conviction of a person owning or controlling such property for a violation of this section, the municipal judge shall order the property confiscated and destroyed. 
(Ord. 1300 § 1, 1991: Ord. 1150 § 1, 1983) 
5.24.020 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, except when the context indicates otherwise: 
    "Cardroom" means any space, room or enclosure furnished or equipped with a table used or intended to be used as a card table for playing a social game and the use of which is available to the public. This definition shall not apply to a bona fide nonprofit society, club or fraternal, religious, civic or educational organization as defined in Section 5.24.130. 
    "Contest of chance" means a contest, game, gaming scheme or gaming device in which the outcome depends in a material degree on an element of chance, notwithstanding that skill of the contestants also may be a factor. 
    "Employee" means employee of the licensee. 
    "Gambling" means when a person stakes or risks something of value on the outcome of a contest of chance or a future contingent event not under the person's control or influence on an agreement or understanding that the person or someone else will receive something of value in the event of a certain outcome. Gambling does not include: 
1.  Social games; 
2.  Bona fide business transactions valid under the law of contracts for the purchase or sale at a future date of securities or commodities and agreements to compensate for loss caused by the happening of chance, including but not limited to contracts of indemnity or guaranty and life, health or accident insurance; or 
3.  Bingo or lotto operated by a charitable, fraternal or religious organization when no person other than the organization or a player profits in any manner from the operation of the lottery and when the organization has complied with the provisions of ORS 167.118 and city ordinances and regulations. 
    "House income" means the receipt of anything of value derived from, but not limited to, any of the following: 
1.  Renting space, chips, equipment or other paraphernalia; 
2.  Raised or excessive charges for services, refreshments or any other item sold or rented in a place where a social game is licensed to be conducted or sold or rented to any player of a social game; 
3.  Placing a specific charge on a social game or on a player of a social game; 
4.  Use of any technique or device that inures to the benefit of a person, private business, private club, place of public accommodation, organization, corporation, partnership, joint venture, or any combination of individuals having a collective capacity. 
    "Social game" means: 
1.  A game, other than a lottery, between players in a private home when no house player, house bank or house odds exist and there is no house income from operation of the game; and 
2.  A game, other than a lottery, between players in a private business, private club, or place of public accommodation when no house player, house bank or house odds exist and there is no income from operation of the game. 
    "Table" means a device or thing on which one social gambling game is conducted. One or more social gambling games may be conducted on the same table, but not simultaneously, in whole or in part. 
(Ord. 1300 § 2, 1991; Ord. 1150 § 2, 1983) 
5.24.030 - Social games. 
    Social games are authorized to be played by those who have attained the age of majority and may be conducted in a private business, private club, or in a place of public accommodation, subject to the provisions of state and local law. 
(Ord. 1150 § 3, 1983) 
5.24.040 - Application for license. 
A.  No person, firm or corporation shall engage in, carry on, maintain or conduct, or cause to be engaged in, carried on, maintained or conducted, a cardroom in the city where social games are played between private parties and items of value or money may be exchanged based upon the winning or losing of the game without having obtained a valid license from the city. Licenses shall be granted only on approval of the council. 
B.  A person making application for a cardroom license shall be the sole and exclusive owner of the table or tables used or to be used in the cardroom. 
C.  If the cardroom to be licensed is owned by a corporation, the license shall issued in the name of the corporation on written application of its president, vice president, secretary or treasurer. If the cardroom to be licensed is owned by a partnership, a partner owning the majority interest or an equal interest in the partnership shall make the written application and the license shall be issued in the partnership name. 
(Ord. 1380 §§ 1, 2, 1997; Ord. 1227 § 1, 1987: Ord. 1176, 1984; Ord. 1150 § 4, 1983) 
5.24.050 - License investigation. 
    An applicant for a cardroom license shall submit an application under oath to the city recorder. The application shall include the true names and addresses, personal histories and business experiences, fingerprints, photographs and past criminal records of all persons who are financially interested in the business and any other matters the city manager considers necessary. The term "person financially interested" includes all persons who share in the profits of the business. The application also shall be accompanied by a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) nonrefundable investigation fee. Effective January 1, 1984, this fee shall be sixty dollars ($60.00). 
(Ord. 1150 § 5, 1983) 
5.24.060 - Granting and denial of application. 
    The council shall either approve the application and grant the license or deny the application and refuse to grant the license. The license shall not be granted if a person who has an interest in the business has: 
A.  Been convicted of a felony within the last ten (10) years; 
B.  Been convicted of five misdemeanors, the last of which was within five years; 
C.  Been convicted of or forfeited bail for a crime involving gambling within the last five years; 
D.  Been involved, directly or indirectly, in a forfeiture proceeding regarding a gambling device as defined in the Oregon Revised Statutes where such gambling device has been ordered destroyed or a bond has been forfeited in lieu of the gambling device being destroyed within the last five years; 
E.  Given false or misleading information or omitted information requested in the application; 
F.  Had a license in the name of the person revoked or suspended three times by the Oregon Liquor Commission, the last of which was in the last five years; 
G.  Been convicted of violation of a law or ordinance involving moral turpitude. 
(Ord. 1150 § 6, 1983) 
5.24.070 - Responsibility of licensee. 
    A licensee shall assign a person to each cardroom to supervise the games and ensure that they are played strictly in accordance with this chapter and provisions of the Oregon Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. 1150 § 7, 1983) 
5.24.080 - Employee work permits. 
    Except as provided in this chapter, employees in cardrooms and employees supervising cardroom activities shall obtain work permits from the city. Applications for work permits shall be obtained from the recorder and shall contain information considered necessary to allow a police background investigation. The city manager may deny a permit based on recommendations from city departments when it is documented that employment should not be permitted. A work permit shall not be issued to a person who has not been a resident of Coos County, Oregon, for at least six months preceding issuance of the permit or who has been involved in conduct described in Section 5.24.060 that would lead to refusal to grant a license. An application for a work permit shall be accompanied by an annual permit fee of ten dollars ($10.00), and a work permit shall be valid for one year. An employee holding a valid Oregon Liquor Control Commission work permit shall not be required to obtain the work permit described in this section. 
(Ord. 1150 § 8, 1983) 
5.24.090 - License not transferable. 
    A cardroom license is not assignable or transferable. A change of persons having financial interest in a licensed business shall be reported immediately in writing to the city manager, who shall order an investigation by the police department and the change shall be approved or denied by the council. An application for change of financial ownership shall be accompanied by a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) nonrefundable investigation fee. Effective January 1, 1984, this fee will be sixty dollars ($60.00). 
(Ord. 1150 § 9, 1983) 
5.24.100 - Suspension and revocation of license. 
A.  The city manager shall temporarily suspend a cardroom license or work permit if a person who has an interest in the business has been involved in conduct described in Section 5.24.060 or if such person or an employee violates any section of this chapter. 
B.  A suspension shall be subject to the right of appeal to the council in regular council session. If written notice of an appeal is not filed with the recorder within ten (10) days after the date of the suspension, the suspension shall be final and conclusive. A temporary suspension shall be for thirty (30) days. 
C.  Permanent revocation may be made only by the council, on application of the city manager. Revocation shall take place at a regular council session at least ten (10) days after the licensee has been served with written notice. Notice shall include the time and date of the council meeting and the grounds on which the permanent revocation is sought. Notice is received by the licensee or permittee if the city manager deposits in the U.S. mail, postage prepaid, a written notice to the address listed by the licensee or permittee on the application for a license or permit. 
(Ord. 1150 § 10, 1983) 
5.24.110 - Regulations. 
A.  No person shall operate a cardroom in violation of any of the following regulations and rules: 
1.  In one hand or round: 
a.  No player shall bet more than ten dollars ($10.00) in money or other thing of value. 
b.  The amount awarded the winner, except for a poker game as provided in subdivision (1)(c) of this subsection, shall not exceed $10 in money or other thing of value multiplied by the number of players in the game. 
c.  In a poker game, there shall be no more than three raises. 
d.  In a 21-game (blackjack), there shall be no more than three hands per player. 
2.  Licensees and permittees holding or obtaining licenses and permits under the provisions of this chapter agree to be bound by and observe each of the terms, conditions and provisions of this chapter. 
3.  Games conducted or operated in the city pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be conducted and operated in full conformity with, and subject to, all provisions of the laws of the state and the ordinances of the city. 
4.  Cardrooms shall be open to police inspection during all hours of operation. Cardroom licenses and work permits shall be available for inspection during all hours of operation. 
5.  No licensee or permittee shall participate in a card game or procure players, back, farm out, assign or sublet card games lawfully permitted under this chapter on the premises in which the licensee or permittee has any interest or works. 
6.  Playing of all card games shall be arranged to provide free access and visibility to interested persons. Doors leading into the cardroom must remain unlocked during all hours of operation. 
7.  No minor shall be permitted to participate in a card game or to enter or remain on the premises. 
8.  No charge shall be collected from a player for the privilege of participating in a game. 
9.  All players in a game, including the dealer, must use their own money. 
B.  The city manager may require one or more of the above rules to be posted in a cardroom in a conspicuous place and in a readable style. 
(Ord. 1227 § 2, 1987; Ord. 1150 § 11, 1983) 
5.24.120 - Cardroom license fees. 
    The cardroom license fee for any period of a calendar year that is more than six months shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) for one table used for social gambling. The cardroom license fee for any period of a calendar year that is six months or less shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for one table used for social gambling. In addition to the cardroom license fee paid for one table used for social gambling, the applicant/licensee shall pay an additional fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each additional table used for social gambling. All license fees are nonrefundable. Other than as provided herein, there shall be no proration of the cardroom license fee. 
(Ord. 1380 § 3, 1997: Ord. 1227 § 4, 1987: Ord. 1150 § 13, 1983) 
5.24.130 - Exceptions to license. 
    A nonprofit society, club or fraternal, religious, civic or educational organization having adopted bylaws and duly elected directors and members may be granted a cardroom license at an annual fee of ten dollars ($10.00) when the tables are for the exclusive use of members of the organization and no charge is made for participation. A license, as provided by this section, may be granted only if the organization has been in continuous existence and actively conducting its affairs in the city for a period of two years immediately preceding application for a license and only if the conduct of the cardroom is not the primary reason for existence of the organization. 
(Ord. 1150 § 14, 1983) 
5.24.140 - Suspension and revocation of table license. 
    Suspension of a cardroom license where a licensed table is located shall automatically suspend the table license. 
(Ord. 1150 § 15, 1983) 
5.24.150 - Expiration of table license. 
    All table licenses and applications for table licenses shall expire at midnight December 31st each year. 
(Ord. 1150 § 16, 1983) 
5.24.160 - Names of employees. 
    On request from a law enforcement officer, a cardroom licensee shall make available the full name and address of any cardroom employee or former employee. 
(Ord. 1150 § 18, 1983) 
5.24.170 - Issuance of licenses and permits. 
    The recorder may issue the licenses and permits provided by this chapter on proper application, approval and fee payment. 
(Ord. 1150 § 19, 1983) 
5.24.180 - Renewal. 
    Cardroom licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter may be renewed by city staff on or before the last working day of any calendar year during which the license is effective without the payment of a new investigative fee, if the application for renewal is the same as the application submitted for the license which is presently effective. Requests for renewal of licenses after the last working day of the year during which the license is effective shall be accompanied by a new investigative fee regardless of whether or not the application is the same as the application submitted for the previous year, and shall be renewed only upon action by the council. 
(Ord. 1227 § 5, 1987: Ord. 1150 § 24, 1983) 
5.24.190 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation of, or failure to comply with, a provision of this chapter is punishable, on conviction, by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. 1150 § 20, 1983) 
Chapter 5.26 - MOTOR VEHICLE FUEL DEALER'S BUSINESS LICENSE 

5.26.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following words and phrases shall mean: 
    "City" means the city of Coquille. 
    "Dealer" means any person who: 
1.  Imports or causes to be imported motor vehicle fuel for sale, use, or distribution in the city, but "dealer" does not include any person who imports into the city motor vehicle fuel in quantities of five hundred (500) gallons or less purchased from a supplier who is licensed as a dealer hereunder if that dealer assumes liability for the payment of the applicable license tax to the city; or 
2.  Produces, refines, manufactures, or compounds motor vehicle fuels in the city for export or for use, distribution or sale in the city; or 
3.  Acquires in the city for sale, use or distribution in the city motor vehicle fuels with respect to which there has been no license tax previously incurred. 
    "Distribution" in addition to its ordinary meaning, means the delivery of motor vehicle fuel by a dealer to any service station or into any tank, storage facility or series of tanks or storage facilities connected by pipelines, from which motor vehicle fuel is withdrawn directly for sale or for delivery into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles whether or not the service station, tank or storage facility is owned, operated or controlled by the dealer. 
    "Highway" means every street, road, way, thoroughfare and place of whatever nature, open for use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel. 
    "Motor vehicle" means all vehicles, engines or machines, movable or immovable, operated or propelled by the use of motor vehicle fuel. 
    "Motor vehicle fuel" means and includes gasoline, diesel, mogas, methanol and any other flammable or combustible gaseous, liquid, or solid substance, by whatever name such substance, is known or sold, usable as fuel for the operation of motor vehicles except a substance, the chief uses of which, as determined by the tax administrator, is for purposes other than the propulsion of motor vehicles upon the highways. 
    "Person" means and includes every natural person, association, firm, partnership, corporation, joint venture or other business entity. 
    "Service station" means any place operated for the purpose of retailing and delivering motor vehicle fuel into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles. 
    "Tax administrator" means the city manager, the city manager's designee, or any person or entity with whom the city manager contract to perform those duties. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.020 - Tax imposed. 
    A business license tax is imposed on every dealer. The tax imposed shall be paid monthly to the tax administrator. The tax administrator is authorized to exercise all supervisory and administrative powers with regard to the enforcement, collection and administration of the business license tax, including all powers specified in the ORS 319.010 to 319.430. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.030 - Amount and payment. 
    In addition to any fee or taxes otherwise provided for by law, every dealer engaging in the city in the sale, use or distribution of motor vehicle fuel, shall: 
A.  Not later than the 25th day of each calendar month, render a statement to the tax administrator on forms prescribed, prepared and furnished by the tax administrator of all motor vehicle fuel sold, use or distributed by him or her in the city as well as all such fuel sold, used or distributed in the city by a purchaser thereof upon which sale, used or distribution the dealer has assumed liability for the applicable license tax during the preceding calendar month. 
B.  Pay a license tax computed on the basis of three cents per gallon of such motor fuel so sold, used or distributed as shown by such statement in the manner and within the time provided in this code. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.040 - License requirements. 
    No dealer shall sell, use or distribute any motor vehicle fuel until he or she has secured a dealer's license as required herein. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.050 - License applications and issuance. 
A.  Every person, before becoming a dealer in motor vehicle fuel in this city, shall make application to the tax administrator for a license authorizing such person to engage in business as a dealer. 
B.  Applications for the license shall be made on forms prescribed, prepared and furnished by the tax administrator. 
C.  Application shall be accompanied by a duly acknowledged certificate containing: 
1.  The business name under which the applicant transacts business; 
2.  The address of applicant's principal place of business and location of distributing stations in and within three miles of the city; 
3.  The name and address of the managing agent, the names and addresses of the several persons constituting the firm or partnership or, if a corporation, the name under which the corporation is authorized to transact business and the names and addresses of its principal officers and registered agent, as well as primary transport carrier. 
D.  If an application for a motor vehicle fuel dealer's license is complete and accepted for filing, the tax administrator shall issue to the dealer a license in such form as the tax administrator may prescribe to transact business in the city, provided, however, that the tax administrator may refuse to issue such license if it finds that the applicant meets any of the conditions for refusal to issue a license under state law. A license issued hereunder is not assignable, and is valid only for the dealer in whose name it is issued. 
E.  The tax administrator shall retain all completed applications with an alphabetical index thereof, together with a record of all licensed dealers. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.060 - Failure to secure license. 
A.  If a dealer sells, distributes or uses any motor vehicle fuel without first filing the certificate and obtaining the license required by Section 5.26.050, the license tax on all motor vehicle fuel sold, distributed or used by that dealer shall be immediately due and payable. 
B.  The tax administrator shall proceed forthwith to determine, from as many available sources as the tax administrator determines reasonable, the amount of tax due, shall assess the dealer for the tax in the amount found due, together with a penalty of one hundred (100) percent of the tax, and shall make its certificate of such assessment and penalty. In any suit or proceeding to collect the tax or penalty or both, the certificate shall be prima facie evidence that the dealer therein named is indebted to the city in the amount of the tax and penalty stated. 
C.  Any tax or penalty assessed pursuant to this section may be collected in the manner prescribed in Section 5.26.100 with reference to the delinquency in payment of the fee or by an action at law. 
D.  In the event any suit or action is instituted to enforce this section, if the city is the prevailing party, the city shall be entitled to recover from the person sued reasonable attorney's fees at trial or upon appeal of such suit or action, in addition to all other sums provided by law. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.070 - Suspension and revocation of license. 
    The tax administrator may, to the extent permitted by law suspend, and upon ten (10) days written notice revoke the license of any dealer who fails to comply with any provision of this chapter. The tax administrator shall mail, by certified mail addressed to the dealer at his or her last known address appearing in the files of the tax administrator, a notice of intent to cancel. The notice of revocation shall include the reason for cancellation. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.080 - Cancellation of license. 
A.  The tax administrator may, upon written request of a dealer, cancel a license issued to that dealer. The tax administrator shall, upon approving the dealer's request for cancellation, set a date not later than thirty (30) days after receipt of the written request, after which the license shall no longer be effective. 
B.  The tax administrator may, after thirty (30) days' notice has been mailed to the last known address of the dealer, cancel the license of dealer upon finding the dealer is no longer engaged in the business of a dealer. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.090 - Remedies cumulative. 
    Except as otherwise provided in Sections 5.26.100 and 5.26.110, the remedies provided in Sections 5.26.060 through 5.26.080 are cumulative. No action taken pursuant to those sections shall relieve any person from the penalty provisions of this code. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.100 - Payment of tax and delinquency. 
A.  The license tax imposed by this chapter shall be paid to the tax administrator on or before the 25th day of each month. 
B.  Except as provided in subsections C and D of this section, if payment of the license tax is not paid as required by subsection A of this section, a penalty of one percent of such license tax shall be assessed and immediately due and payable. 
C.  Except as provided in subsection D of this section, if the payment of the tax and penalty, if any, is not made on or before the 1st day of the next month following that month in which payment is due, a further penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax shall be assessed. Said penalty shall be in addition to the penalty provided for in subsection B of this section and shall be immediately due and payable. 
D.  Penalties imposed by this section shall not apply if a penalty has been assessed and paid pursuant to Section 5.26.060. The tax administrator may for good cause shown waive any penalties assessed under this section. 
E.  If any person fails to pay the license tax or any penalty provided for by this section, the tax and/or penalty shall be collected from that person for the use of the city. The tax administrator shall commence and prosecute to final determination in any court of competent jurisdiction as action at law to collect the same. 
F.  In the event any suit or action is instituted to collect the business license tax or any penalty provided for by this section, if the city is the prevailing party, the city shall be entitled to recover from the person sued reasonable attorney's fees at trail or upon appeal of such suit or action, in addition to all other sums provided by law. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.110 - Monthly statement of dealer. 
    Every dealer in motor vehicle fuel shall provide to the tax administrator on or before the 25th day of each month, on forms prescribed, prepared and furnished by the tax administrator, a statement of the number of gallons of motor vehicle fuel sold, distributed or used by the dealer during the preceding calendar month. The dealer or the dealer's agent shall sign the statement. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.120 - Failure to file monthly statement. 
    If a dealer fails to file any statement required by Section 5.26.110, the tax administrator shall proceed forthwith to determine from as many available sources as the tax administrator determines reasonable the amount of motor vehicle fuel sold, distributed or used by such dealer for the period unreported, and such determination shall in any proceeding be prima facie evidence of the amount of fuel sold, distributed or used. The tax administrator shall immediately assess the dealer for the license tax upon the amount determined, adding thereto a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax. The penalty shall be cumulative to other penalties provided in this code. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.130 - Billing purchasers. 
    Dealers in motor vehicle fuel shall render bills to all purchasers of motor vehicle fuel. The bills shall separately state and describe the different products sold or shipped thereunder and shall be serially numbered except where other sales invoice controls acceptable to the tax administrator are maintained. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.140 - Failure to provide invoice or delivery tag. 
    No person shall receive and accept motor vehicle fuel from any dealer, or pay for the same, or sell or offer the motor vehicle fuel for sale, unless the motor vehicle fuel is accompanied by and invoice or delivery tag showing the date upon which motor vehicle fuel was delivered, purchased or sold and the name of the dealer in motor vehicle fuel. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.150 - Transporting motor vehicle fuel in bulk. 
    Every person operating any conveyance for the purpose of hauling, transporting or delivering motor vehicle fuel in bulk shall, before entering upon the public highways of the city with such conveyance, have and possess during the entire time of the hauling or transporting of such motor vehicle fuel, an invoice, bill of sale or other written statement showing the number of gallons, the true name and address of the seller or consignor, and the true name and address of the buyer or consignee, if any, of the same. The person hauling such motor vehicle fuel shall, at the request of any officer authorized by law to inquire into or investigate such matter, produce and offer for inspection the invoice, bill of sale or other statement. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.160 - Exemption of export fuel. 
A.  The license tax imposed by Section 5.26.020 shall not be imposed on motor vehicle fuel: 
1.  Exported from the city by a dealer; or 
2.  Sold by a dealer in individual quantities of five hundred (500) gallons or less for export by the purchaser to an area or areas outside the city in containers other than the fuel tank of a motor vehicle, but every dealer shall be required to report such exports and sales to the city in such detail as may be required. 
B.  In support of any exemption from license taxes claimed under this section other than in the case of stock transfers or deliveries in the dealer's own equipment, every dealer must execute and file with the tax administrator an export certificate in such form as shall be prescribed, prepared and furnished by the tax administrator, containing a statement, made by some person having actual knowledge of the fact of such exportation, that the motor vehicle fuel has been exported from the city, and giving such details with reference to such shipment as the tax administrator may require. The tax administrator may demand of any dealer such additional data as is deemed necessary in support of any such certificate, and failure to supply such data will constitute a waiver of all right to exemption claimed by virtue of such certificate. The tax administrator may, in a case where the tax administrator believes no useful purpose would be served by filing of an export certificate, waive the filing of the certificate. 
C.  Any motor vehicle fuel carried from the city in the fuel tank of a motor vehicle shall not be considered as exported from the city. 
D.  No person shall, through false statement, trick or device, or otherwise, obtain motor vehicle fuel for export as to which the city tax has not been paid and fail to export the same, or any portion thereof, or cause the motor vehicle fuel or any portion thereof not to be exported, or divert or cause to be diverted the motor vehicle fuel or any portion thereof to be used, distributed or sold in the city and fail to notify the tax administrator and the dealer from whom the motor vehicle fuel was originally purchased of his or her act. 
E.  No dealer or other person shall conspire with any person to withhold from export, or divert from export or to return motor vehicle fuel to the city for sale or use so as to avoid any of the fees imposed herein. 
F.  In support of any exemption from taxes on account of sales of motor vehicle fuel in individual quantities of five hundred (500) gallons or less for export by the purchaser, the dealer shall retain in his or her files for at least three years, an export certificate executed by the purchaser in such form and containing such information as is prescribed by the tax administrator. This certificate shall be prima facie evidence of the exportation of the motor vehicle fuel to which is applies only if accepted by the dealer in good faith. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.170 - Sales to armed forces exempted. 
    The license tax imposed by Sections 5.26.020 and 5.26.030 shall not be imposed on any motor vehicle fuel sold to the Armed Forces of the United States for use in ships, aircraft or for export from the city; but every dealer shall be required to report such sales to the tax administrator in such detail as may be required. A certificate by an authorized officer of such armed forces shall be accepted by the dealer as sufficient proof that the sale is for the purpose specified in the certificate. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.180 - Fuel in vehicles coming into city not taxed. 
    Any person coming into the city in a motor vehicle may transport in the fuel tank of such vehicle, motor vehicle fuel for his or her own use only and for the purpose of operating such motor vehicle without securing a license or paying the tax provided in Sections 5.26.020 and 5.26.030 or complying with any of the provisions imposed upon dealers herein, but if the motor vehicle fuel so brought into the city is removed from the fuel tank of the vehicle or used for any purpose other than the propulsion of the vehicle, the person so importing the fuel into the city shall be subject to all the provision herein applying to dealers. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.190 - Refunds. 
    Refunds will be made pursuant to applicable Chapter 319 of the Oregon Revised Laws. Claims forms for refunds may be obtained from the tax administrator's office. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007) 
5.26.200 - Examinations and investigations. 
    The tax administrator, or duly authorized agents, may make any examination of accounts, records, stocks, facilities and equipment of dealers, service stations and other persons engaged in storing, selling or distributing motor vehicle fuel or other petroleum product or products within this city, and such other investigations it considers necessary in carrying out the provisions of this chapter. If the examinations or investigations disclose that any reports of dealers or other persons theretofore filed with the tax administrator pursuant to the requirements herein, have show incorrectly the amount of gallonage of motor vehicle fuel distributed or the tax accruing thereon, the tax administrator may make such changes in subsequent reports and payments of such dealers or other persons, or may make such refunds, as may be necessary to correct the errors disclosed by its examinations or investigation. The dealer shall reimburse the city for the reasonable cost of the examination or investigation if the action discloses that the dealer paid ninety-five (95) percent or less of the tax owing for the period of the examination or investigation. In the event that such an examination or investigation results in an assessment by and an additional payment due to the city, such additional payment shall be subject to interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per year from the date of the original tax payment was due. 
(Ord. 1462 § 1 (part), 2007)
