B.  If the owner violates any term of the stipulation entered into according to subsection A of this section; the entire bond shall be forfeited. 
(Ord. 1376 § 8, 1996) 
Chapter 9.20 - WEAPONS 

9.20.010 - Discharging firearms. 
    Except as set out in Section 9.20.030, no person, other than a peace officer acting in the line of duty or a person acting in lawful defense of person or property, shall discharge a firearm within the city limits. 
(Ord. 1409 § 1, 2000: Ord. 1296 § 2, 1991) 
9.20.020 - Discharging air guns. 
    Except on a person's own property or as set out in Section 9.20.030, no person shall discharge an air gun within the city limits. 
(Ord. 1296 § 3, 1991) 
9.20.030 - Designated locations to discharge firearms. 
    Nothing herein shall prohibit the common council of the city from designating locations within the city limits at which the discharging of firearms or air guns may be allowed. No such location shall be approved by the council unless adequate provisions are made for public safety and noise containment. 
(Ord. 1296 § 4, 1991) 
Title 10 - VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC 
Chapters: 
Chapter 10.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS, ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
Sections: 

10.04.010 - Short title. 
    This title may be cited as the city uniform traffic ordinance. 
(Ord. 1375 § 1, 1997) 
10.04.020 - Definitions. 
A.  In addition to those definitions contained in the Oregon Vehicle Code, the following words and phrases, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, shall mean as follows: 
    "Bus stop" or "taxicab stand" means a space on the edge of a roadway designated by sign for use by buses or taxis loading or unloading passengers. 
    "Holiday" means Sunday, New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Veteran's Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, and any other day proclaimed by the council to be a holiday. 
    "Loading zone" means a space on the edge of a roadway designated by sign for the purpose of loading or unloading passengers or materials during specific hours of specified days. 
    "Vehicle" means every vehicle that is self-propelled, including tractors, fork-lift trucks, motorcycles, road building equipment, street cleaning equipment, and any other vehicle capable of moving under its own power, notwithstanding that the vehicle may be exempt from licensing under the motor vehicle laws of Oregon. Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public highway and includes vehicles that are propelled or powered by any means, such as, but not limited to, skateboards and bicycles. 
    "Officer" means a patrol person employed by the city or any authorized law enforcement officer, including, but not limited to, the city employee designated to enforce parking regulations. 
    "Owner" means the person in whose name title to a vehicle is issued or in whose name the vehicle is registered, and who is entitled to possession and use of the vehicle and/or the person, lessor or lessee of a vehicle who is entitled to the possession and use of the vehicle under an agreement. 
    "Person" means a natural person, firm, partnership, association or corporation. 
    "Street" means every public way, road, highway, alley, thoroughfare and place, including bridges, viaducts and other structures. 
    "Traffic lane" means that area of the roadway used for the movement of a single line of traffic. 
B.  As used in this title, the singular includes the plural; and the masculine includes the feminine. 
(Ord. 1375 § 2, 1997) 
10.04.030 - Powers of the council. 
A.  Subject to state law, the city council shall exercise all municipal traffic authority for the city except those powers specifically and expressly delegated herein or by another ordinance. 
B.  The council may, by resolution, establish or alter traffic controls which shall become effective upon the installation of appropriate signs, signals or other markings. Powers of the council shall include, but not be limited to: 
1.  Designation of through streets; 
2.  Designation of one-way streets; 
3.  Designation of truck routes; 
4.  Designation of parking meter zones; 
5.  Restriction of the use of certain streets by any class or kind of vehicle to protect the streets from damage; 
6.  Authorization of greater maximum weights or lengths for vehicles using city streets than specified by state law; 
7.  Initiation of proceedings to change speed zones; 
8.  Revision of speed limits in parks; 
9.  Designation of parking zones and time limits for parking. 
C.  The city council has the power to act, by resolution, to establish, amend or change a system for the use of parking permits, which permits shall allow parking for time periods in excess of time limits established by other actions of the city council and shall further have authority to establish, amend or change, as part of the parking permit system, procedures for the use of parking permits and fees for the costs of parking permits authorized by this title. 
D.  The city council may, by resolution, establish, amend or change a schedule of fines for illegal, prohibited or improper parking. 
(Ord. 1375 § 3, 1997) 
10.04.040 - Duties of the city manager. 
    The city manager or his/her designate shall exercise the following duties: 
A.  Implement the ordinances, resolutions and motions of the council and his, her own orders by installing, maintaining, removing and altering traffic control devices. Such installation shall be based on the standards contained in the Oregon Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways; 
B.  Establish, remove or alter the following classes of traffic controls: 
1.  Crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes, 
2.  Intersection channelization and areas where drivers of vehicles shall not make right, left, or U-turns, and the time when the prohibition applies, 
3.  Parking areas and time limitations, including the form of permissible parking (e.g., parallel or diagonal); 
C.  Issue oversize or overweight vehicle permits. 
(Ord. 1375 § 4, 1997) 
10.04.050 - Public danger. 
    Under conditions constituting a danger to the public, the city manager or his or her designate may install temporary traffic control devices deemed by him or her to be necessary. 
(Ord. 1375 § 5, 1997) 
10.04.060 - Basis of standards. 
    The regulations of the city manager or his or her designate shall be based upon: 
A.  Traffic engineering principles and traffic investigations; 
B.  Standards, limitations and rules promulgated by the Oregon Transportation Commission; 
C.  Other recognized traffic control standards. 
(Ord. 1375 § 6, 1997) 
10.04.070 - Authority of police and fire officers. 
A.  It shall be the duty of police officers and others designated by the city manager to enforce the provisions of this title. 
B.  In the event of a fire or other public emergency, officers of the police and fire department may direct traffic as conditions require, notwithstanding the provisions of this title. 
(Ord. 1375 § 7, 1997) 
10.04.080 - Violations-Penalties. 
A.  Violation of Sections 10.08.010 through 10.08.060 and 10.12.010 is punishable by a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
B.  Violation of Sections 10.08.070 through 10.08.090 and 10.12.020 through 10.12.120 is punishable by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00). 
C.  Except as specified in this title, the minimum fine and minimum bail for the violation of overtime parking regulations and resolutions heretofore adopted by the common council shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
D.  Violation of a provision identical to a state statute is punishable by fine or bail not to exceed the penalty prescribed in the state statute. 
E.  Except as provided in subsection (D) of this section, the common council shall have authority to change the minimum fine or bail by resolution. 
(Ord. 1375 § 36, 1997) 
Chapter 10.08 - MISCELLANEOUS TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

10.08.010 - Crossing private property. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall proceed from one street to an intersecting street by crossing private property. This provision shall not apply to the operator of a vehicle who stops on the property for the purpose of procuring or providing goods or services. 
(Ord. 1375 § 8, 1997) 
10.08.015 - Truck routes. 
A.  Motor Truck Traffic Prohibited. 
1.  Except as provided in subsection 2., no person shall operate any motor truck upon any public street or alley within the city unless such street or alley has been designated as a truck route. 
2.  Motor trucks being operated on public streets for the following specific purposes are exempt from the restriction imposed by subsection 1. above: 
a.  Picking up or discharging goods at any business establishment or residence in the city; 
b.  Going to or from a business in the city for the purpose of fuel, service, or repair; 
c.  Servicing utility facilities or construction sites in the city; or 
d.  Traveling to or from the driver's residence while unloaded. 
    Such exempted vehicles shall depart from and return to the nearest available truck route for each exempted trip, they shall not cut through non-truck route areas between stops. 
3.  For purposes of this section, "motor truck" means every motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property and having a gross weight in excess of twenty-six thousand (26,000) pounds, excluding emergency governmental vehicles and city franchised vehicles. 
B.  Truck Routes Established. Those streets, roads, and highways located within the limits of the City of Coquille are hereby designated as truck routes: 
1.  Mill Street; 
2.  Adams Street from Highway 42 to Third Street; 
3.  Third Street from Adams Street to Central Avenue/Boulevard; 
4.  Central Avenue/Boulevard from Third Street to the Coquille city limits; 
5.  Fairview Road from Central Avenue to the Coquille city limits. 
C.  Other Requirements. In addition to the state motor vehicle laws prohibiting parking, no person shall park or stand: 
1.  A vehicle in an alley other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of persons or materials, and in no case for a period in excess of thirty (30) consecutive minutes. 
2.  Any loaded motor truck on any street within a residential district within the city; excepting, however, certain service vehicles, utility company trucks when actually going to, performing or coming from work which normally falls within the scope of the utility companies' construction, maintenance and repair work, and moving vans when actually engaged in moving or transporting goods. 
3.  Within that area between the curb or the curb line and the abutting property line commonly known as the planting strip, or on or over a sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 1489, § 1(Exh. A), 10-7-2013) 
10.08.020 - Unlawful riding. 
A.  No operator shall permit a passenger and no passenger shall ride on a vehicle upon a street except on a portion of the vehicle designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or to a person riding within a truck body in space intended for merchandise. 
B.  No person shall ride on the outside of a truck, the side rails or hood; however, riding in the bed of the truck is permitted in accordance with state law. 
C.  No person shall board or alight from a vehicle while the vehicle is in motion upon a street. 
(Ord. 1375 § 9, 1997) 
10.08.030 - Sleds on streets. 
    No person shall use the streets for traveling on skis, toboggans, sleds or similar devices, except where authorized. 
(Ord. 1375 § 10, 1997) 
10.08.040 - Damaging sidewalks and curbs. 
A.  The operator of a motor vehicle shall not drive upon a sidewalk or roadside planting strip except to cross at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
B.  No unauthorized person shall place dirt, wood or other material in the gutter or space next to the curb or move a motor vehicle or device moved by a motor vehicle upon a curb or sidewalk without first obtaining authorization and posting bond if required. A person who causes damage shall be held responsible for the cost of repair. 
(Ord. 1375 § 11, 1997) 
10.08.050 - Removing glass and debris. 
    A party to a vehicle accident or a person causing broken glass or other debris to be upon a street shall remove the glass and other debris from the street. 
(Ord. 1375 § 12, 1997) 
10.08.060 - Obstructing streets. 
    No person shall park or leave on a street, parking strip, sidewalk or curb, any vehicle part, trailer, box, merchandise of any description, or any other thing that impedes traffic or obstructs the view, except as is allowed by this or other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. 1375 § 14, 1997) 
10.08.070 - Pedestrians must use crosswalks. 
A.  No pedestrian shall cross a street other than within a crosswalk in blocks where crosswalks are marked. 
B.  Where there is no marked crosswalk, pedestrians shall cross a street at the closest intersection. 
(Ord. 1375 § 28, 1997) 
10.08.080 - Pedestrian walking. 
    Where sidewalks are provided, no pedestrian shall walk along and upon the adjacent roadway. 
(Ord. 1375 § 29, 1997) 
10.08.090 - Funeral processions. 
A.  A funeral procession shall proceed to the place of interment by the most direct route which is both legal and practical. 
B.  The procession shall be accompanied by adequate escort vehicles for traffic control purposes. 
C.  All motor vehicles in the procession shall be operated with their lights turned on. 
D.  No person shall unreasonably interfere with a funeral procession. 
E.  No person shall operate a vehicle that is not a part of the procession between the vehicles of a funeral procession. 
F.  Each driver in the procession shall follow the vehicle ahead as closely as is practical and safe. 
(Ord. 1375 § 30, 1997) 
10.08.100 - Moving railway cars. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person, except as hereinafter provided, to get onto or off any moving railway car or train within the corporate limits of the city; provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply to any person or employee of a railway company, whose regular business, in whole or in part, is to handle freight for a railway company or any person or employee whose employment requires that person or employee to assist in handling cars or trains for a railway company or anything transported or to be transported on the company's trains or cars. 
B.  Any person found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this section shall be adjudged to pay a fine of not less than five dollars ($5.00) and not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. 1408 § 1, 2000; Ord. 930 § 1, 1976: Ord. 4-87 §§ 1, 2, 1905) 
Chapter 10.12 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
Sections: 

10.12.010 - Unlawful vehicles or personal property on streets. 
    No person shall park or place or permit to be parked or placed on a street or other public property, without permission of the council, a vehicle or personal property for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours in a commercial area and seventy-two (72) hours in any other area. Failure to move a vehicle or other personal property for a period of twenty-four (24) hours in a commercial area and seventy-two (72) hours in any other area shall constitute prima facie evidence of unlawful vehicle parking or unlawful placing of personal property on streets. 
(Ord. 1375 § 13, 1997) 
10.12.020 - Method of parking. 
A.  Where parking space markings are placed on a street, no person shall stand or park a vehicle other than in the indicated direction and, unless the size or shape of the vehicle makes compliance impossible within a single marked space. 
B.  The operator who first begins maneuvering a motor vehicle into a vacant parking space on a street shall have priority to park in that space, and no other vehicle operator shall attempt to interfere. 
C.  Whenever the operator of a vehicle discovers the vehicle is parked close to a building to which the fire department has been summoned, the operator shall immediately remove the vehicle from the area unless otherwise directed by police or fire officers. 
(Ord. 1375 § 15, 1997) 
10.12.030 - Prohibited parking or standing. 
    No person shall park or stand: 
A.  A vehicle in violation of the Oregon Vehicle Code or in violation of a lawfully erected parking limitation sign or marking; 
B.  A vehicle in an alley, except for a stop of not more than thirty (30) consecutive minutes for loading or unloading persons or material; 
C.  A vehicle upon any parkway, except where authorized by the city. 
(Ord. 1468 § 2, 2008; Ord. 1375 § 16, 1997) 
10.12.040 - Prohibited parking. 
    No operator shall park and no owner shall allow a vehicle to be parked upon a street for the principal purpose of: 
A.  Displaying the vehicle for sale; provided, however, an automobile dealer selling new cars at an established place of business in the city may, at the time of the introduction of new models of vehicles that such dealer sells, but for not more than two of such items per year nor more than three business days during each of such times, display the new model vehicles at a regular vehicle parking place, not to exceed six parking stalls upon the street adjacent to the car dealer's place of business. Advertising for the sale of such model or models of new vehicles may be displayed on the vehicle. 
1.  Prior written notice shall be given to the Coquille police department of the intent to exercise the privilege granted to the dealer hereunder, 
2.  Time limits for parking shall be suspended during the exercise of the privilege granted hereunder; 
B.  Repairing or servicing the vehicle, except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
C.  Displaying advertising from the vehicle, except when authorized. 
(Ord. 1375 § 17, 1997) 
10.12.050 - Use of loading zones. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time, other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of persons or materials, in a place designated as a loading zone when the hours applicable to that loading zone are in effect. 
(Ord. 1375 § 18, 1997) 
10.12.060 - Unattended vehicles. 
    Whenever a police officer shall find a motor vehicle parking or standing unattended with the ignition key in the vehicle, the officer is authorized to remove the key from the vehicle and deliver the key to the person in charge of the police station. The officer shall affix a notice to the vehicle indicating where the owner of the vehicle can pick up the key. 
(Ord. 1375 § 19, 1997) 
10.12.070 - Standing or parking of buses and taxicabs. 
    The operator of a bus or taxicab shall not stand or park the vehicle upon a street in a business district at a place other than a bus stop or taxicab stand, respectively; except that this provision shall not prevent the operator of a taxicab from temporarily storing the taxicab outside a traffic lane while loading or unloading passengers. 
(Ord. 1375 § 20, 1997) 
10.12.080 - Restricted use of bus and taxicab stands. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, or a bus in a bus stop, except that the operator of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when stopping does not interfere with a bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter the restricted space. 
(Ord. 1375 § 21, 1997) 
10.12.090 - Extension of parking time. 
    Where maximum parking time limits are designated by sign, movement of a vehicle within a block shall not extend the time limits for parking. Continued parking beyond the single limit for any parking space shall constitute a separate offense for each period or portion of a single limit for any such parking space during which the vehicle remains parked. 
(Ord. 1375 § 22, 1997) 
10.12.100 - Exemption. 
    The provision of this title that regulate the parking or standing of vehicles do not apply to: 
A.  A vehicle of the city, county, state or a public utility while necessarily in use for construction or repair work on a street; 
B.  A vehicle owned by the United States while in use for the collection, transportation or delivery of mail; 
C.  A vehicle of a disabled person who complies with the provisions pertaining to disabled persons as set forth in the Oregon Vehicle Code; 
D.  Emergency vehicles performing their duty. 
(Ord. 1375 § 23, 1997) 
10.12.110 - Prior parking regulations. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this title, all parking resolutions heretofore duly enacted under authority of city are and shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 1375 § 24, 1997) 
10.12.120 - Citation of illegally parked vehicle. 
    Whenever a vehicle without an operator is found parked in violation of a restriction imposed by this title or state law, the officer finding the vehicle shall take its license number, and any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its owner, and shall conspicuously affix to the vehicle a traffic citation. The citation shall instruct the operator to answer to the charge by appearing before the court on the date specified in the citation or that the operator may waive the appearance by paying the penalty assessment (bail) imposed on or before the court date during the hours and at a place specified in the citation. 
(Ord. 1375 § 31, 1997) 
10.12.130 - Failure to comply with parking citation. 
A.  First Notice. If the operator does not respond to a parking citation affixed to the vehicle in either manner described in Section 10.12.120, the city shall double the bail and mail a notice to the owner of the vehicle informing the owner of the parking violation and that the bail indicated in the parking citation has been doubled. The notice shall further inform the owner that if the citation is disregarded for a period of fifteen (15) days from the date of the notice, the bail will be doubled a second time. 
B.  Second Notice. If the owner does not pay the bail pursuant to the first notice described in subsection A of this section, the bail shall be doubled a second time and a second notice indicating the increased amount of bail shall be sent to the owner. The notice shall inform the owner that the twice-doubled bail must be paid within fifteen (15) days of the date of the notice or the owner must personally appear. Failure to pay within the time period stated in this subsection or failure to appear shall be deemed a guilty plea, and a fine in an amount equal to twice the amount of the bail imposed under this subsection shall be levied by the municipal court. The second notice shall also state that such fine shall be assigned to a professional collection agency for collection. 
(Ord. 1385 §§ 2, 3, 1998: Ord. 1375 § 32, 1997) 
10.12.140 - Owner responsibility. 
    The owner of a vehicle placed in violation of a parking restriction shall be responsible for the offense, except when the use of the vehicle was secured by the operator without the owner's consent. 
(Ord. 1375 § 33, 1997) 
10.12.150 - Registered owner presumption. 
    In a prosecution of a vehicle owner charging a violation of a restriction on parking, proof that the vehicle at the time of the violation was registered to the defendant shall constitute a presumption that the defendant was then the owner in fact. 
(Ord. 1375 § 34, 1997) 
10.12.160 - Impoundment of vehicles. 
A.  Whenever a vehicle is placed in a manner or location that constitutes an obstruction to traffic or a hazard to public safety, a police officer shall order the owner or operator of the vehicle to remove it. If the vehicle is unattended, the officer may cause the vehicle to be towed and stored at the owner's expense. The owner shall be liable for the costs of towing and storing, notwithstanding that the vehicle was parked by another person or that the vehicle was initially parked in a safe manner but subsequently became an obstruction or hazard. 
B.  The disposition of a vehicle towed and stored under authority of this section shall be in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 8.12 enacted relating to the impoundment and disposition of discarded vehicles in the city. 
C.  The impoundment of a vehicle will not preclude the issuance of a citation for violation of a provision of this title. 
D.  Stolen vehicles may be towed from public or private property and stored at the expense of the vehicle owner. 
E.  Whenever a police officer observes a vehicle in violation of a provision of this title or state law, if the owner of the vehicle has in excess of fifteen dollars ($15.00) in outstanding fines levied against the owner, the officer may, in addition to issuing a citation, cause the vehicle to be impounded. A vehicle so impounded shall not be released until all outstanding fines and charges have been paid. Vehicles impounded under authority of this subsection shall be disposed of in the same manner as is provided in subsection B of this section. 
(Ord. 1375 § 35, 1997) 
Chapter 10.16 - IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.16.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "City" means the city of Coquille. 
    "Department of Transportation" means the Oregon Department of Transportation, or other registration authority analogous to the Department of Transportation in any state other than Oregon. 
    "Person" means an individual; a corporation, partnership or other legal entity, and entity in fact. 
    "Police department" means the police department of the city. 
    "Police officer" means an employee or reserve of the police department officially designated by the department as an officer. 
(Ord. 1384 § 1, 1998) 
10.16.020 - Towing and impounding without notice. 
    A police officer, without prior notice to the owner or operator of a motor vehicle, may cause a motor vehicle to be towed and impounded under the following circumstances: 
A.  When the police officer reasonably believes the operator is driving the motor vehicle uninsured or without other means to prove financial responsibility as required by ORS 806.010; 
B.  When the motor vehicle is illegally parked on a public street, private street, parking lot, or in a restricted space, zone or traffic lane where parking is limited or prohibited to designated classes of vehicles or during designated period of time, or where the motor vehicle at any time interferes with the intended use of such restricted space, zone or traffic lane; 
C.  When the operator of the motor vehicle does not possess or cannot produce a valid operator's license; 
D.  When the motor vehicle is in the possession of a person taken into custody by the police officer and no other reasonable disposition of the motor vehicle is available; 
E.  When the motor vehicle has not been registered or the operator is unable to produce a valid registration card; 
F.  When a police officer has good cause to believe the motor vehicle is stolen; 
G.  When a vehicle is left on public right of way in such a location or manner as to create a hazard or obstruction to traffic. 
(Ord. 1384 § 2, 1998) 
10.16.030 - Towing and impounding after notice. 
    A police officer may provide written notice of intent to impound when the officer reasonably believes the vehicle is abandoned as provided in Section 10.16.020(G). Notice shall be sent to the owner of the vehicle and any lessors or security interest holders as shown in the records of the Department of Transportation, and must state that the vehicle will be towed unless the owner removes the vehicle within five days of the date of mailing; notice of intent to impound shall also be posted in a conspicuous place on the vehicle, and must state the vehicle will be towed on a date not later than five days after the date of posting. Failure to provide notice under this section shall not affect the validity of any action taken to tow and impound an abandoned vehicle pursuant to Section 10.16.020. 
(Ord. 1384 § 3, 1998) 
10.16.040 - Inventory of vehicle. 
A.  Time of Conducting Inventory. The contents of any vehicle which is to be towed and impounded shall be inventoried by the police officer. The police officer shall conduct a complete inventory of the contents of the vehicle. The inventory shall be conducted prior to towing, impounding and/or seizing the vehicle except where there is a reasonable suspicion that the safety of the police officer or other person is at risk, in which case the inventory shall be made as soon as safely practical. 
B.  Purpose of Inventory. The inventory shall be made for the following purposes only: 
1.  To promptly identify personal property for the protection of such property while the vehicle is impounded, towed or seized; 
2.  To prevent false claims for lost or stolen property; 
3.  To locate toxic, flammable, explosive or other dangerous substances. 
C.  Area of Vehicle to be Inventoried. The inventory shall be conducted throughout the passenger, engine compartments and storage areas of the vehicle, including, but not limited to, accessible areas under or within the dashboard areas, pockets in the doors or the back of the front seats, in any consoles between seats, and under floor mats and seats. 
D.  Property to be Inventoried. Inventories of the following property shall be made: 
1.  Of all personal property in plain view or in open containers; 
2.  All open containers and any contents therein found in any unlocked compartments, including the trunk, glove box and car-top carriers; 
3.  All open containers and any contents therein found in any locked compartments; 
4.  All closed containers and any contents therein. As used in this subsection, "closed container" means any container secured in such a manner that a reasonable person would know or should know that access requires permission. 
E.  Written Inventory List. The police officer shall prepare a written list of property inventoried contemporaneously with the inventory. The inventory list shall be signed, dated, including the time the inventory was started and completed. A copy of the inventory shall be filed with the police department. A copy shall be left with the vehicle, and a copy shall be tendered to the person in possession or control of the vehicle if that person is present at the time of impounding, towing or seizing of the vehicle. A copy shall also be provided with the required notice under Section 10.16.070. 
F.  Notice. Within forty-eight (48) hours after a vehicle has been towed, impounded or seized, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays, the police department shall determine the identity of the owner of the vehicle through the Department of Transportation records and send the owner, and the person in control of the vehicle if present at the time of impounding, towing or seizing of the vehicle, a notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, stating the following: 
1.  That the vehicle has been towed and impounded and that the contents of the vehicle are in the custody of the police department; 
2.  The reason why the vehicle has been towed and why it and its contents have been impounded; 
3.  The location of the vehicle and the address and telephone number that may be used to obtain information regarding the charges that must be paid before the vehicle or its contents will be released and the procedures for procuring such release; 
4.  That the vehicle and its contents are subject to towing and storage charges, the amount of the charges that have accrued as of the date of the notice, the rate of the daily storage charges and that the daily storage charges will continue to accrue; 
5.  That the vehicle and its contents may be immediately reclaimed upon presenting proof of ownership or right to possession of the contents to the police department and paying any fee to the police department as specified in Section 10.16.070, and paying to the person who towed and is storing the vehicle and/or its contents all towing and storage charges; 
6.  That the person who towed and is storing the vehicle and/or its contents has a lien on the vehicle for the towing and storage charges, and will retain possession of the vehicle and its contents until the charges are paid and, if the charges remain unpaid for more than thirty (30) days, may have the vehicle and/or its contents sold to satisfy the lien; 
7.  That the vehicle and/or its contents may be sold or otherwise disposed of if a person entitled to possession of the vehicle and/or its contents does not reclaim the vehicle and/or its contents within thirty (30) days of the date the vehicle and its contents were towed and impounded. 
(Ord. 1384 § 4, 1998) 
10.16.050 - When notice not required. 
    No notice is required as provided under subsection F of Section 10.16.040 under the following circumstances: 
A.  The vehicle does not display license plates or other identification by which registration or ownership of the vehicle can be determined; and 
B.  The identity of the owner of the vehicle is not available from the Oregon Department of Transportation records or other registration authority, or the identity and address of the owner cannot be otherwise reasonably determined. 
(Ord. 1384 § 5, 1998) 
10.16.060 - Effect of notice. 
    If the owner of the vehicle and any lessors or security interest holders as shown in the records of the Department of Transportation do not contact the city, in writing, within thirty (30) days of the date the notice is provided, or thirty (30) days from the date of towing and impoundment if no notice is required, then the vehicle shall be deemed an abandoned vehicle. 
(Ord. 1384 § 6, 1998) 
10.16.070 - Release of vehicle. 
    A vehicle towed and impounded shall be released to a person entitled to lawful possession upon payment to the city of a fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Upon payment of the fee, the city shall authorize the person storing the vehicle to release the vehicle upon payment of towing and storage charges. Entitlement to lawful possession shall be established by the owner presenting proof of current ownership, proof of insurance and financial responsibility and proof of a valid operator's license; provided, however, if the person seeking release does not have a valid operator's license, the person may be accompanied by a licensed driver, who shall operate the vehicle after release. If the person seeking release is the holder of a validly perfected security interest, then entitlement to lawful possession shall be established by presentation of a certified copy of the document creating the security interest, along with a copy of a letter to the owner, with proof of mailing, providing notice that the vehicle will be released to the secured party. 
(Ord. 1384 § 7, 1998) 
10.16.080 - Hearing to contest the validity of towing and impoundment. 
A.  A request for hearing must be filed with the police department by the owner of the vehicle within ten (10) days of receipt of the Notice under Section 10.16.040. The request must be in writing, and shall state with particularity the basis of the owner's objection to the towing and impoundment of the vehicle. Failure to timely file a request for hearing shall be a waiver of right to hearing. 
B.  Hearing shall be held within four calendar days of a timely filed request, excluding Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays before an impartial hearings officer appointed by the city. The city shall have the burden of proving the validity of the towing and impoundment by a preponderance of the evidence. 
C.  If the hearings officer finds the towing and impoundment of the vehicle was improper, the vehicle shall be ordered release to the person entitled to possession, and the city shall pay charges for towing and storage. 
D.  Appeal of the decision by the hearings office shall be by Writ of Review under ORS 34.010-34.100. 
(Ord. 1384 § 8, 1998) 
10.16.090 - Towing and storage liens. 
A.  A person who tows and impounds a vehicle pursuant to this chapter shall have a lien on the vehicle for just and reasonable towing and storage charges, may retain the vehicle until the charges are paid, or, if the charges are unpaid for the time specified herein, may have the vehicle sold to satisfy the lien. The lien shall be a possessory chattel line as provided in ORS 87.152 and shall be perfected and foreclosed in the manner provided in ORS 87.152-87.212. 
B.  A person who tows a vehicle pursuant to this chapter is immune from civil liability for towing the vehicle, unless loss, damage or injury to the vehicle is the result of the person's negligent or wilful acts. 
(Ord. 1384 § 9, 1998) 
10.16.100 - Disposition of vehicles and contents. 
A.  If a vehicle is not reclaimed within thirty (30) days after it is impounded, the City may dispose of the vehicle and its contents. 
B.  At least ten (10) days prior to disposing of the vehicle and/or its contents the city shall give the person who towed and is storing the vehicle written notice of the city's intent to dispose of the vehicle under this section. 
C.  At any time after thirty (30) days from the date that notice has been provided pursuant to Section 10.16.040, or thirty (30) days after the date the vehicle was towed if no notice required pursuant to Section 10.16.050, the city may initiate proceedings to sell the vehicle and its contents. The sale may be at private or public auction. 
D.  The city shall have the vehicle appraised by a person who has been issued an appraiser's certificate by the Oregon Department of Transportation. That person shall photograph the vehicle and shall notify the Department of Transportation that the city will be disposing of the vehicle. 
E.  Notice of sale of the vehicle shall be given to the owner and any lessors and security interest holders as shown in the records of the Department of Transportation, by registered or certified mail at least thirty (30) days prior to the sale. In addition, the city shall post a notice of sale in a public placed located within the Coquille City Hall. The notice of sale shall contain a specific description of the vehicle, the name of the owner, the amounts due under this ordinance for towing, storage and any other charges, and the time, place and manner of sale. If the vehicle is appraised at a value of two thousand five hundred dollars $2,500.00 or greater, notice of sale shall be printed once a week for two successive weeks in a daily or weekly newspaper generally circulated in Coos County. 
F.  A person holding a security interest may, prior to sale, obtain release of the vehicle by providing entitlement to possession as required by Section 10.16.070, by paying the amounts due under this ordinance under Section 10.16.070 and by paying the towing and storage charges. 
G.  If through no fault of the city's, a person holding a security interest in the vehicle fails to obtain release of the vehicle as provided herein, the person's security interest is extinguished. 
H.  If the city fails to notify a person holding a properly perfected security interest of the sale as required by this section, then the vehicle remains subject to the security interest, and any subsequent purchaser takes the vehicle subject to the security interest. 
I.  Disposal. 
1.  If the vehicle is appraised at a value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less, the city may dispose of the vehicle and its contents by sale to a person who holds a valid wrecker's certificate issued under ORS 822.110, or may dispose of the vehicle at public auction. 
2.  If the vehicle is appraised at a value less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) but more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), the city may dispose of the vehicle and its contents by sale to a person who holds a valid wrecker's certificate issued under ORS 822.110 if: 
a.  The owner of the vehicle, any lessor or holder of a security interest shown in the records of the Department of Transportation signs a release, under oath, disclaiming any interest in the vehicle; or 
b.  The owner of the vehicle, any lessor or holder of a security interest shown in the records of the Department of Transportation have been provided with notice as provided in Section 10.16.040 of this chapter, and have failed to sign a release or reclaim the vehicle. 
3.  Except as provided in subsection (I)(2) of this section, where the vehicle is appraised at a value less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) but more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), the vehicle shall be sold at public auction. 
4.  If the vehicle is appraised at a value of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more, the city shall sell the vehicle at public auction. 
J.  Upon sale and payment of the purchase price, the city shall execute a certificate of sale in duplicate. The original certificate of sale shall be delivered to the purchaser and the copy shall be retained by the city. The certificate of sale shall contain the name and address of the purchaser, the date of sale, the purchase price paid, a description of the vehicle and a stipulation that the sale is without any warranty as to the condition or title of the vehicle. The purchaser shall be notified that the purchaser might be required to apply for a salvage title under ORS 819.010. The purchaser shall be entitled to be issued title and a registration card for the vehicle, or to be issued a salvage title to the vehicle. 
K.  Return of Sale and Proceeds of Sale. 
1.  When a vehicle is sold pursuant to this section, the city shall provide a return of sale to the Department of Transportation setting forth a description of the vehicle, the purchase price, the name and address of the purchaser, the costs incurred in the sale, and the costs and expenses incurred in the removal, preservation and custody of the vehicle. 
2.  The city shall deduct from the proceeds of the sale the costs incurred in the sale and the costs and expenses incurred in the removal, preservation and custody of the vehicle; provided, however, that the city shall only disburse proceeds to the person who towed and stored the vehicle if that person properly perfected their lien under ORS 87.176. 
3.  The city's finance officer shall then deposit the proceeds from the sale in a fund specifically designated for such purpose, and shall file a copy of the return of sale, along with a copy of any notices required by this section in the records of the city. 
4.  At any time within two years after the sale of a vehicle, the former owner or former security interest holder may recover the proceeds, minus costs incurred in the sale and costs of removal, preservation and custody of the vehicle, and fees charged pursuant to Section 10.16.070 of this chapter, together with interest at the statutory rate, by filing a claim with the city, proving the person's ownership or security interest in the vehicle as of the date of the sale. 
5.  If no person has filed a claim within two years of the date of sale, then the proceeds shall be deposited in the city's general fund. 
(Ord. 1384 § 10, 1998) 
Chapter 10.20 - BICYCLES, SKATEBOARDS, ROLLER SKATES, ROLLER BLADES, SCOOTERS AND MOTORIZED SCOOTERS 
Sections: 

10.20.010 - Operating rules. 
    In addition to observing all other applicable provisions of this title and state law pertaining to bicycles, skateboards, roller skates, roller blades, scooters and motorized scooters, a person shall: 
A.  Not leave a bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter so as to obstruct any roadway, sidewalk, driveway or building entrance. A person shall not leave these objects in violation of the provisions of this title or state law relating to the parking of vehicles; 
B.  Not ride a bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter upon a sidewalk within the C-1 zoning district (commercial/business district) of the city, or on the sidewalks, porch, parking areas and driving areas of the Coquille Community Services Building. 
(Ord. 1451 § 2 (part), 2004: Ord. 1375 § 25, 1997) 
10.20.020 - Renting of bicycles, scooters or motorized scooters. 
    No person shall rent or offer a bicycle, scooter or motorized scooter for rent unless the bicycle, scooter or motorized scooter is equipped in accordance with the Oregon Vehicle Code. 
(Ord. 1451 § 2 (part), 2004: Ord. 1375 § 26, 1997) 
10.20.030 - Impounding of bicycles, skateboards, roller skates, roller blades, scooters and motorized scooters. 
A.  No person shall leave a bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter on public or private property without the consent of the person in charge or the owner thereof. 
B.  A bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter left on public property for a period in excess of twenty-four (24) hours may be impounded by the police department. 
C.  In addition to any citation issued, a bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter placed in violation of this chapter may be immediately impounded by the police department. 
D.  If a bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter is impounded under the provisions of this title and the owner of such objects can be readily determined, the police shall make reasonable efforts to notify the owner. No impounding fee shall be charged to the owner of a stolen bicycle, skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter or motorized scooter which has been impounded. 
E.  A bicycle impounded under this title which remains unclaimed shall be disposed of in accordance with the city's procedures for disposal of abandoned or lost personal property. 
F.  Except as provided in subsection D of this section, a fee of two dollars shall be charged to the owner of a bicycle impounded under this section. 
(Ord. 1451 § 2 (part), 2004: Ord. 1375 § 27, 1997) 
[Text continues pg. 115] 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - JURISDICTION OVER PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
Sections: 

12.04.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter: 
    "City" means the city of Coquille, Oregon. 
    "Person" means individual, corporation, association, firm, partnership, joint stock company, and similar entities. 
    "Public rights-of-way" includes, but is not limited to, streets, roads, highways, bridges, alleys, sidewalks, trails, paths, public easements and all other public ways or areas, including subsurface and air space over these areas. 
    "Within the city" means territory over which the city now has or acquires jurisdiction for the exercise of its powers. 
(Ord. 1377 § 1, 1997) 
12.04.020 - Jurisdiction. 
    The city has jurisdiction and exercises regulatory control over all public rights-of-way within the city under the authority of the city charter and state law. 
(Ord. 1377 § 2, 1997) 
12.04.030 - Scope of regulatory control. 
    The city has jurisdiction and exercises regulatory control over each public right-of-way whether the city has a fee, easement, or other legal interest in the right-of-way. The city has jurisdiction and regulatory control over each right-of-way whether the legal interest in the right-of-way was obtained by grant, dedication, prescription, reservation, condemnation, annexation, foreclosure or other means. 
(Ord. 1377 § 3, 1997) 
12.04.040 - City permission requirement. 
    No person may occupy or encroach on a public right-of-way without the permission of the city. The city grants permission to use rights-of-way by franchises, licenses and permits. 
(Ord. 1377 § 4, 1997) 
12.04.050 - Obligations of the city. 
    The exercise of jurisdiction and regulatory control over a public right-of-way by the city is not official acceptance of the right-of-way, and does not obligate the city to maintain or repair any part of the right-of-way. 
(Ord. 1377 § 5, 1997) 
Chapter 12.08 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Right to harvest crops grown on right-of-way. 
A.  The owner, contract purchaser, or lessee of real property that abuts a street right-of-way shall be entitled to have the exclusive use and possession of all fruit and vegetable crops grown thereon, and to have such use and possession free from interference from any other person. 
B.  It is unlawful for any person to interfere with such owner's, contract purchaser's, or lessee's use, possession, and enjoyment of such fruit and vegetables and the trees or plants on which the same grow. 
C.  Nothing contained in this section shall be construed as a license or grant to plant any of the trees or shrubs within the prohibitions of Chapter 12.16, or to maintain anything within the boundaries of such street right-of-way in violation of any ordinance of the city. 
D.  Upon conviction of a violation of this section or any part hereof, a fine of not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be levied. 
(Ord. 930 § 1, 1976: Ord. 849 §§ 1-4, 1971) 
12.08.020 - Objects on sidewalks. 
A.  Obstructions on Sidewalks. Other than as authorized by Section 9.12.030, or except as allowed pursuant to subsection B of this section, no person, firm or corporation shall place objects on sidewalks in the commercially zoned areas of the city. 
B.  Permitted Objects on Sidewalks. Self-service dispensers of newspapers, decorative plants, plant holders, benches and freestanding or temporary signs, including sandwich boards, may be placed on sidewalks in commercially zoned areas of the city if a permit has first been obtained from the city manager, or designee. In issuing, denying or revoking such permit, the city manager, or designee, shall first determine whether the location and size of any such object will obstruct the free-flow of pedestrian traffic, whether the placement of such object has the consent of the adjoining property owner and ground floor occupant, whether the placement and use of such object will be aesthetically displeasing to the general public, and whether the placement will create a public or private danger to the patrons of the city. In no event shall the unobstructed portion of the sidewalk be less than six feet wide. 
C.  Appeal to the City Council. Any person adversely affected by the denial or revocation by the city manager, or designee, as set forth in subsection B of this section, may appeal to the city council from such ruling. Such appeal must be by written notice filed with the city recorder within ten days from the date of such ruling. The city council shall have the power to affirm, overrule or modify any such ruling. 
(Ord. 1339 §§ 1-3, 1993) 
Chapter 12.12 - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 
Sections: 

12.12.010 - Definitions. 
    Unless the context requires otherwise: 
    "Person" means a natural person, firm, corporation or other legal entity. 
    "Sidewalk" means the part of the street right-of-way between the curblines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines that is intended for the use of pedestrians. 
(Ord. 1138 § 1, 1983) 
12.12.020 - Duty to repair and clear sidewalks. 
    It is the duty of an owner or occupant of land adjoining a street to maintain in good repair, and remove obstructions from, the adjacent sidewalk. 
(Ord. 1138 § 2, 1983) 
12.12.030 - Liability for sidewalk injuries. 
A.  The owner of real property responsible for maintaining the adjacent sidewalk shall be primarily liable to any person injured because of any negligence of such owner in failing to maintain the sidewalk in good condition. 
B.  If the city is required to pay damages for an injury to persons or property caused by the failure of a person to perform the duty which this section imposes, the person shall compensate the city for the amount of damages thus paid. The city may maintain an action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 1138 § 3, 1983) 
12.12.040 - Standards and specifications. 
    Sidewalks shall be constructed, altered and repaired in accordance with the standards and specifications established by the city council. 
(Ord. 1138 § 4, 1983) 
12.12.050 - Submission of plans. 
    No person shall construct, alter or repair a sidewalk without first submitting the plans and specifications for the proposed work to the public works director and obtaining his or her approval. After determining that the proposed work conforms to the applicable standards and specifications established under Section 12.12.030, the public works director shall give his or her approval for the proposed work. 
(Ord. 1138 § 5, 1983) 
12.12.060 - Supervision of work. 
    The construction, alteration or repair of sidewalks shall be under the supervision of the public works director. The public works director may inspect any materials and construction details as in his or her judgment may be necessary to insure compliance with the applicable standards and specifications. 
(Ord. 1138 § 6, 1983) 
12.12.070 - Required sidewalk repairs. 
A.  When the council determines that a sidewalk needs repair, it shall, by resolution, direct the public works director to issue a notice. 
B.  The notice shall require the owner of the property adjacent to the defective sidewalk to complete the repair of the sidewalk within thirty (30) days after the service of notice. The notice shall also state that if the repair is not made by the owner, the city may repair the sidewalk, and the cost of the repair will be assessed against the property adjacent to the sidewalk. 
C.  The public works director shall cause a copy of the notice to be served personally upon the owner of the property adjacent to the defective sidewalk, or the notice may be served by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested. If after diligent search the owner is not discovered, the public works director shall cause a copy of the notice to be posted in a conspicuous place on the property, and such posting shall have the same effect as service of notice by mail or by personal service upon the owner of the property. 
D.  The person serving the notice shall file with the recorder a statement stating the time, place and manner of service of notice. 
(Ord. 1138 § 7, 1983) 
12.12.080 - Objections to required repairs. 
    An owner may object to notice of required sidewalk repairs by giving notice in writing to the public works director within ten (10) days of the owner's receipt of notice sent in accordance with Section 12.12.070. Upon receipt of the notice by the public works director, a hearing shall be held at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the common council. The common council shall conduct a hearing to consider the objections raised and may amend its prior resolution by motion only as the common council deems appropriate. 
(Ord. 1138 § 8, 1983) 
12.12.090 - City may make repairs. 
    If repair of the sidewalk is not completed within thirty (30) days after the service of the notice to repair, the public works director may repair or complete the repair of the sidewalk or the public works director may hire a contractor or contractors to complete the work as directed by the resolution of the common council. On completion of the repair of the sidewalk, the public works director shall submit a report to the council. The report shall contain an itemized statement of the cost of the repair and the proportionate share of the cost of each lot or parcel of land adjacent to the sidewalk on which the repair has been made. 
(Ord. 1146 § 1, 1983: Ord. 1138 § 9, 1983) 
12.12.100 - Assessment for repairs by city. 
A.  If the city completes the construction or repair as provided in Section 12.12.090, the city shall forward a notice to the owner, by registered or certified mail, stating: 
1.  The total cost of construction or repair, including the administrative costs; 
2.  That the costs as indicated will be assessed to and become a lien against the property unless paid within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice; 
3.  That if the owner objects to the cost of construction or repair as indicated, a notice of objection may be filed with the city not more than ten (10) days from the date of the notice. 
B.  No sooner than thirty (30) days after the date of the notice, the council, in the regular course of business, shall hear and make a decision on the objections to the costs assessed. 
C.  If the costs of construction or repair are not paid within thirty (30) days from the date of the notice, an assessment of the costs, as stated or as decided by the council, shall be made by ordinance and shall be entered in the docket of city liens. When the entry is made, it shall constitute a lien on the property and may be collected in the same manner as provided for the collection of street improvement assessments. 
(Ord. 1146 § 2, 1983: Ord. 1138 § 10, 1983) 
12.12.110 - Construction of sidewalks. 
A.  The cost of constructing a sidewalk shall be borne by the owner of the property on which the sidewalk abuts. 
B.  If a property owner petitions the council for an order to build a sidewalk on the part of the street abutting on his property, agrees to pay cash or to make application to pay the cost in installments as provided by the Bancroft Bonding Act (ORS 223.205 et seq.), waives the right of remonstrance, service and publication of notice of construction and the calling of bids, and consents to the assessment of the property upon which the sidewalk is to abut, the Council may order the construction of the requested improvement, if in its judgment the improvement should be made. 
(Ord. 1304, 1991; Ord. 1138 § 11, 1983) 
12.12.120 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation of this chapter is punishable by fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day's violation of a provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1138 § 12, 1983) 
Chapter 12.16 - STREET TREES 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall hereafter be referred to and cited as the street tree ordinance of the city of Coquille, Oregon. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 1, 1959) 
12.16.020 - Enforcing authority. 
    The city manager or his or her duly authorized representative shall be charged with the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 2, 1959) 
12.16.030 - Permission to plant trees. 
    No trees or shrubs shall hereafter be planted in or removed from any public parking strip or other public place in the city without permission of the city manager. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 3, 1959) 
12.16.040 - Street tree plan. 
    All trees and shrubs hereafter planted in any public parking strip or other public place in the city shall conform as to species and location as may from time to time be provided by the council by resolution, motion or ordinance. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 4, 1959) 
12.16.050 - Prohibited trees. 
    It is unlawful to plant in any public parking strip the following trees: poplar, willow, conifer, cottonwood, fruit trees, nut trees, ailanthus. 
    It is unlawful to plant willow, cottonwood or poplar trees anywhere in the city unless the city manager approves the site as one where the tree roots will not interfere with a public sewer. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 5, 1959) 
12.16.060 - Removal of trees. 
    The city manager or his or her duly authorized representative may cause to be trimmed, pruned or removed any trees, shrubs, plants or vegetation in any parking strip or other public place, or may require any property owner to trim, prune or remove any trees, shrubs, plants or vegetation in a parking strip abutting upon the owner's property; and failure to comply therewith, after thirty (30) days' notice by the city recorder, shall be deemed a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 6, 1959) 
12.16.070 - Dangerous trees declared nuisance-Summary powers to remove same. 
    Any tree or shrub growing in a parking strip or any public place, or in private property, which is endangering or which in any way may endanger the security or usefulness of any water main, public street, sewer, or sidewalk, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and the city may remove or trim such tree, or may require the property owner to remove or trim any such tree on private property or in a parking strip abutting upon the owner's property. Failure of the property owner to remove or trim such tree after thirty (30) days' notice by the city recorder shall be deemed a violation of this chapter; and the city manager may then remove or trim the tree and assess the costs against the property. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 7, 1959) 
12.16.080 - Appeals. 
    Appeals from orders made hereunder may be made by filing written notice thereof with the city recorder within ten (10) days after such order is received, stating in substance that appeal is being made from such order to the city council. The recorder shall thereupon call such appeal to the attention of the city council at the next regular succeeding meeting, at which meeting the appellant and the city manager may present evidence. Action taken by the city council after such hearing shall be conclusive. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 8, 1959) 
12.16.090 - Abuse or mutilation of trees. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter to abuse, destroy, or mutilate any tree, shrub or plant in a public parking strip or any other public place, or to attach or place any rope or wire (other than one used to support a young or broken tree), sign, poster, handbill or other thing to or on any tree growing in a public place, or to cause or permit any wire charged with electricity to come in contact with any such tree, or to allow any gaseous, liquid or solid substance which is harmful to such trees to come in contact with their roots or leaves. 
(Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 9, 1959) 
12.16.100 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or failing to comply with them shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. 930 § 1, 1976: Ord. 946 (part), 1976: Ord. 5-321 § 10, 1959) 
Chapter 12.20 - PARKS 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Alcoholic liquor" means any alcoholic beverage containing more than one and one-half of one percent alcohol by volume, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, and capable of being consumed by a human being. 
    "City council" means common council of the city of Coquille. 
    "City manager" means the person appointed by the city council to oversee city services. 
    "City of Coquille" means a political subdivision of the state of Oregon. 
    "Horse" means horse, mule, donkey or other rideable animal. 
    "Motor vehicle" means any self-propelled vehicle or vehicle designed for self-propulsion. 
    "Park employee" means an employee of the city of Coquille public works department. 
    "Park" means an area designated by the city as a public park, community activity area or recreation area, including, but not limited to, the Coquille Community Building and all adjacent city-owned property surrounding the community building. 
    "Pets" means any animal kept for domestic purposes. 
    "Public works department" means the city's public works department, its director, employees and agents. 
(Ord. 1404 § 1, 2000; Ord. 1355 § 1, 1994) 
12.20.020 - Park closure. 
A.  The city manager, or his or her designate, is authorized to close to public use any City park or portion thereof, or restrict the times when the same shall be open to such use, or limit or prohibit any recreational use whenever, in his or her judgment, such actions are necessary to protect the public health, safety or welfare, or for the protection of the park or any of its facilities. 
B.  Any closure beyond three days shall be authorized by order of the city council. 
C.  Reasonable cause for closure or restricted use shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
1.  Extreme fire hazard; 
2.  Dangerous water or weather conditions; 
3.  Public works department construction or repairs; 
4.  Conservation of fish and wildlife; 
5.  Excessive boat traffic; 
6.  Unsafe or crowded shoreline, ramps, parking or road conditions; 
7.  Damage to a park or any of its facilities; 
8.  Any dangerous, unsafe or unhealthful condition. 
D.  A park employee may, as conditions warrant, close the park at any time of the day or night to any new arrivals in order to limit the number of person using day-use and camping facilities on any given day or in any twenty-four (24) hour period. Any such closure to new arrivals will last only so long as the park employee believes necessary to prevent overcrowding. 
E.  Closure time for all day use areas shall be ten p.m. unless otherwise posted. 
(Ord. 1355 § 2, 1994) 
12.20.030 - Fees and permits. 
A.  All fees and charges, including permits issued by the city authorizing the use of a park or any of its areas or facilities, shall be in accordance with the schedules adopted from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
B.  No person shall enter or use any park or any of its facilities without first paying the prescribed fee, if any, to the city. 
C.  No person shall refuse to exhibit to any park employee, upon demand, any permit issued to that person by the city. 
(Ord. 1355 § 3, 1994) 
12.20.040 - Authority to revoke permits. 
A.  A park employee may revoke any permit issued unlawfully or erroneously or when he or she has reasonable cause to believe the permit holder has violated any provisions of this chapter or state law. A park employee may also expel such person from the park. 
B.  A park employee may take possession of any revoked or fictitious permit. 
(Ord. 1355 § 4, 1994) 
12.20.050 - Motor vehicles. 
A.  Within a park no person shall: 
1.  Drive a motor vehicle at a speed greater than five miles per hour in a picnic area, campground, or parking lot, or at a speed greater than ten (10) miles per hour in any other area unless otherwise posted; 
2.  Drive a motor vehicle on other than established vehicular roads, parking areas or boat ramps, except those areas specifically designated for such use; 
3.  Drive an unlicensed motor vehicle or drive a motor vehicle without a valid operator's license; 
4.  Drive any motor vehicle in a reckless manner or in wanton disregard for the safety of persons or property; 
5.  Drive a motorcycle, other than for entry or exit, into the park. 
B.  The city may, at the owner's expense, move or remove any motor vehicle trailer or tent which is parked or sited in violation of this chapter. 
C.  Within a park no person shall park or leave a boat or boat trailer in any other area other than those areas clearly designated for such purpose or as otherwise authorized by a park employee. 
(Ord. 1355 § 5, 1994) 
12.20.060 - Sturdivant Park-Motor vehicle restrictions. 
A.  No person shall operate a motor vehicle off of the traveled portion of any graveled or asphalt roadway located within the real property described above, commonly known as Sturdivant Park. 
B.  No person shall operate a motor vehicle at a speed in excess of ten (10) miles per hour within the confines of the boundaries of the real property, commonly known as Sturdivant Park. 
C.  Penalty. Violation of any provision of this section is punishable as follows: 
1.  Upon conviction of a first offense, a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00); 
2.  Upon conviction of a second or subsequent offense, a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
    In addition to the provision for a fine as provided for herein, any person convicted of a violation of this section which has resulted in pecuniary damages to the city, the court may order that the convicted person make restitution to the city in addition to any other sentence it may impose for the pecuniary damages caused by the person's conduct. 
(Ord. 1201, 1985; Ord. 1133 §§ 1, 2, 1982) 
12.20.070 - Animals. 
A.  Pets are not permitted in any park except as specifically designated therein. A park employee may refuse to admit any person to a park who possesses a pet or other animal that appears in the judgment of the park employee to be dangerous or likely to disturb other persons in the park. 
B.  In those parks or park areas where pets are permitted, the following regulations shall apply: 
1.  No person shall allow any pet to run unrestrained without prior permission from the city. Pets shall be restrained by a secure leash not over ten (10) feet long. 
2.  No person shall allow any pet in his/her custody to annoy or molest any person. 
3.  No person shall allow any pet in his/her custody to be tied up and left unattended. 
4.  No person shall drive, ride, lead or keep a horse in any park, except in areas designated for that purpose without prior permission from city. 
5.  No person shall bring any animal, other than a seeing eye dog, into any park building. 
C.  No person shall pursue, kill, injure, hunt, molest or in any manner disturb any bird or animal within a park, except as may be permitted by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. 1355 § 6, 1994) 
12.20.080 - Firearms, other weapons and explosives. 
    Within a park no person shall: 
A.  Discharge any firearm, pellet gun, wrist rocket, bow and arrow, slingshot, or any other missile launching device, except in those areas designated by the parks department for such use; 
B.  Possess or use any fireworks or other explosives without prior permission from the city. 
(Ord. 1355 § 7, 1994) 
12.20.090 - Fires. 
A.  Fires in park areas shall be confined to: 
1.  Park camp stoves or fireplaces provided for such purposes; 
2.  Portable stoves in established campsites or park picnic areas where fires are permitted. 
B.  No fire shall be left unattended or be permitted to cause damage to park facilities or areas. Every fire shall be extinguished before its users leave the park area. 
C.  At the discretion of the park employee, fires normally permitted in park areas may be restricted or prohibited due to high fire hazard conditions. 
(Ord. 1355 § 8, 1994) 
12.20.100 - Overnight camping. 
A.  No person shall camp in any park without a camping permit. Camping shall be confined to areas specifically designated for such use. A park employee may revoke a camping permit if the permit holder does not maintain the campsite, in a reasonably clean, sanitary and safe manner. 
B.  No person shall remove, vandalize or destroy any valid permit displayed at a campsite. 
C.  A camping permit will expire after a maximum of ten (10) days. No camping permit shall be issued for camping in a City park for a period in excess of ten (10) days within any thirty (30) day period. The thirty (30) day period shall be calculated commencing on the first day a camping permit is issued or the first day the person begins camping in the park, whichever occurs first. 
D.  All camping permits expire at two-thirty p.m. on the expiration date. 
E.  Overnight campers under eighteen (18) years of age must be accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
F.  No persons shall reserve or attempt to reserve a campsite. 
G.  No persons shall operate or use any noise producing machine, vehicle, device or instrument in such a manner that is disturbing to other park visitors. 
(Ord. 1355 § 9, 1994) 
12.20.110 - Special events or group activities. 
    Any person intending to conduct special events or group activities, including, but not limited to, weddings, receptions, club meetings, company picnics and parties, shall obtain a permit from the parks department at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the activity or event to be conducted. All activities must comply with state laws. The permit holder shall pay, in advance, any clean up fee or deposit established by the city council. 
(Ord. 1355 § 10, 1994) 
12.20.120 - Alcoholic beverages. 
    Notwithstanding Section 9.08.050 which prohibits the use of alcohol in public places, alcoholic beverages are not prohibited in Sturdivant Park as long as the use of such beverage does not create a nuisance as that term is described by ordinance in this code. 
(Ord. 1381 § 1, 1997: Ord. 1355 § 11, 1994) 
12.20.130 - Refuse. 
    Within a park no person shall: 
A.  Throw, dump or deposit any trash, refuse, garbage, litter or waste material, except in receptacles designated by the parks department for that purpose; 
B.  Bring into a park any trash, refuse, garbage, litter, waste material or vehicle for the purpose of leaving it therein; 
C.  Throw, dump or deposit into the water of a lake or stream, or the banks thereof, any trash, refuse, garbage, litter, waste material or any other polluting products of any kind; 
D.  Clean any fish, except at places designated by the city for this purpose. 
(Ord. 1355 § 12, 1994) 
12.20.140 - Noise. 
    In addition to the provisions of the general offense of unreasonable or unnecessary noise as described in Section 9.08.020, any person(s) occupying camping sites, using the park for day use, recreational purposes or any other type of use shall refrain from creating any noise that disrupts, disturbs or interferes with any other person(s) use and enjoyment of the park area. 
(Ord. 1381 § 2, 1997: Ord. 1355 § 13, 1994) 
12.20.150 - Damage, displacement or removal of park property. 
    No person shall, within a city park: 
A.  Pick, cut, mutilate or remove flowers, shrubs, foliage or trees without permission from the city; 
B.  Mutilate, deface, damage or remove any park equipment, including but not limited to tables, benches, buildings, signs, markers, plaques, barriers, fountains, faucets, traffic recorders or other structures or facilities; 
C.  Dig, dredge, deface or remove any dirt, stones, rocks, artifacts or other substances, make any excavation, quarry stones or other objects, or cause or assist in doing any of the things except with written permission from the city. 
(Ord. 1355 § 14, 1994) 
12.20.160 - Concessions. 
    The city council is desirous of having private concessions within the parks. Each proposal will be considered on a case by case basis with a fee schedule set by the city council. The license requirements and other requirements for each type of concession will be determined by resolution of the council. 
(Ord. 1355 § 15, 1994) 
12.20.170 - Enforcement. 
    Any peace officer, as defined by ORS 161.015, may enforce this chapter. Any park employee may expel from a park any person violating this chapter. 
(Ord. 1355 § 17, 1994) 
12.20.180 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is a civil infraction subject to a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each day that a violation of this chapter continues constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. 1355 § 16, 1994) 
Chapter 12.24 - PARADES 
Sections: 

12.24.010 - Prohibited activity. 
    No person shall organize or participate in a parade which may disrupt or interfere with traffic without obtaining a permit. A permit shall always be required of a procession of people utilizing the public right-of-way and consisting of ten (10) or more persons or forty (40) or more vehicles. 
(Ord. 1375 § 37, 1997) 
12.24.020 - Parade permit. 
A.  Application for parade permits shall be made to the city manager at least twelve (12) days prior to the intended date of the parade, unless the time is waived by him or her. 
B.  Applications shall include the following information: 
1.  The name and address of the person responsible for the proposed parade; 
2.  The date of the proposed parade; 
3.  The desired route including assembling points; 
4.  The number of persons, vehicles and animals which will be participating in the parade; 
5.  The proposed starting and ending time. 
C.  The application shall be signed by the person designated as chairperson, or person in charge. 
D.  If the city manager, upon receipt of the application, determines that the parade can be conducted without endangering public safety and without seriously inconveniencing the general public, he or she shall approve the route and issue the permit. 
E.  If the city manager determines that the parade cannot be conducted without endangering public safety or seriously inconveniencing the general public, he or she may: 
1.  Propose an alternate route; 
2.  Propose an alternate date; 
3.  Refuse to issue a parade permit. 
F.  The city manager shall notify the applicant of his or her decision within five days of receipt of the application. 
G.  If the city manager proposes alternatives or refuses to issue a permit, the applicant shall have the right to appeal the decision to the city council. 
(Ord. 1375 § 38, 1997) 
12.24.030 - Appeal to council. 
A.  An applicant may appeal the decision of the city manager by filing a written request of appeal with the city recorder within five days after the city manager has proposed alternatives or refused to issue a permit. 
B.  The council shall schedule a hearing date which shall not be later than the second regular session following the filing of the written appeal with the city recorder and shall notify the applicant of the date and time that he or she may appear either in person or by representative. 
(Ord. 1375 § 39, 1997) 
12.24.040 - Offenses against parade. 
A.  No person shall unreasonably interfere with a parade or parade participant. 
B.  No person shall operate a vehicle that is not part of a parade between the vehicles or persons comprising a parade. 
(Ord. 1375 § 40, 1997) 
12.24.050 - Permit revocable. 
    The city manager may revoke a parade permit if circumstances clearly show that the parade can no longer be conducted consistent with public safety. 
(Ord. 1375 § 41, 1997) 
12.24.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation of this chapter is punishable by a fine not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. 1375 § 36(2), 1997) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER SERVICE SYSTEM 

13.04.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter and Chapter 13.12, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    "Account maintenance fee" means the nonrefundable payment accompanying an application for water service to pay for the cost of setting up a new account, initial meter reading and other administrative expenses. 
    "Commercial establishment" means any building or establishment or portion thereof engaging in any activity other than for residential purposes. Commercial does not include dwellings, residential courts, manufactured home park, or water districts. 
    "City" means the city of Coquille. 
    Dwelling, Multiple. "Multiple dwelling" means a building designed and used for occupancy by three or more families, all living independently of each other and having separate housekeeping facilities for each family. This includes apartments. 
    Dwelling, Manufactured Home.
