"Manufactured home dwelling" means any portable structure or vehicle which is constructed and designed to permit human occupancy thereof and which is being used for residential purposes, including manufactured and mobile homes. For the purposes of this definition, it shall not be relevant: 
1.  Whether the vehicle or structure is placed upon property for temporary, semi-permanent or permanent use; or 
2.  That the wheels may be removed allowing the vehicle or structure to be placed on posts, footings or a foundation. 
    Dwelling, Single-Family. "Single-family dwelling" means a building designed and used exclusively for the occupancy of one family and having housekeeping facilities for only one family. 
    Dwelling, Two-Family. "Two-family (duplex) dwelling" means a building designed and used exclusively for the occupancy of two families living independently of each other and having housekeeping facilities for each family. 
    "EDU" means the city-wide average monthly winter water consumption for a single family residence based upon the months of November through April. 
    "Family" means one or more persons related by blood, marriage or legal adoption or legal guardianship, a group of not more than five unrelated persons living together as a single nonprofit housekeeping unit and using common housekeeping facilities. 
    "Housekeeping facility" means a structure or portion thereof providing living, sleeping, meal preparation, and restroom facilities for one individual family. 
    "Landowner" means the person(s) in fee title to, or the contract purchaser of, the real property, as evidenced by the Deed Records of Coos County, and shall not include a tenant or person having leasehold interest in the property. 
    "Manufactured home park" means any lot, tract or parcel of land under the same ownership where two or more, or a combination of two or more manufactured or mobile homes, are used for human occupancy and parked or sited within five hundred (500) feet of one another. 
    "Residence" means any dwelling. 
    "Residential court" means a group of two or more connected or unconnected residences, or recreational vehicle sites, erected on one parcel of land and designated primarily for transient or tourist rentals of less than one month and includes, but is not limited to, hotels, motels and recreational vehicle parks. 
    "Unit" means a structure, whether in whole or in part, in which a dwelling or commercial establishment exists. Units shall be calculated as follows: 
1. Single-family dwelling 1 unit 2. Two-family dwelling 2 units 3. Multiple dwelling 1 unit for each housekeeping facility 4. Manufactured home dwelling 1 unit 5. Manufactured home park 1 unit for each manufactured home, site, or pad 6. Residential court 1 unit for each three rental units 7. Commercial establishment 1 unit for each separate business or occupant which has a securable exterior door to separate the unit from other businesses and/or occupants and allows for the ability of each business oroccupant to have independent hours of operation from each other.  
    "Unit service charge" means the service charge to each unit connected by single or multiple connections to a meter. 
    "Water lateral" means the piping system between the main pipe to, and including, the water meter. 
    "Water service" means the process of supplying and distributing potable water. 
    "Water service line" means the piping from the water meter to, and servicing of, a subject property. 
(Ord. 1444 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1442 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1402 § 1, 2000) 
13.04.020 - Application for water service. 
A.  Every application for water service shall be in writing on a form approved by the city, and shall be accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the common council of Coquille. 
B.  Applicants for water service outside of the city boundaries shall execute a form containing the following agreement: 
Application is hereby made for water service at Premises known as  (address)  outside the city of Coquille, Oregon. It is understood and agreed that if this service is allowed, the undersigned owner or occupant of the Premises referred to herein shall pay the rate prescribed by city ordinance from time to time for service at that location; that this service shall be a special contract service and not provided by the city as a common utility service; that the quantity of water supplied by this service may be reduced or the service entirely discontinued at any time when the city council finds such action necessary in order to provide sufficient service to the inhabitants within the city limits, inasmuch as water service beyond the limits is a service of surplus water not needed within the city; that at least 30 days notice in writing shall be given by the city before such discontinuance may be put into effect; that notice delivered at the Premises or at the last known address of the owner or applicant shall be sufficient; that the undersigned owner may discontinue service without advance notice of more than one day, but shall be responsible for all water served to the Premises by the city until notice in writing is given of such discontinuance. 
Date: ____________ 
Owner: ____________ 
C.  The account maintenance fee for water service shall be determined by resolution of the common council of the city. 
D.  The application of an applicant who has not established a continuous, regular and prompt payment record for water service with the city for a period of thirty-six (36) consecutive calendar months or more, must include, in addition to the account maintenance fee, the following: 
1.  A utility payment deposit as determined by resolution of the common council of the city for each unit (as defined herein) that is to receive water service; or 
2.  An agreement signed by the owner of the property where water service is being requested, on a form provided by the city recorder, consenting to a lien upon the premises where water service is being provided. The lien shall be against the premises served from the date of recording and billing of such services on the city's records relating to its water system for water and sewer charges to the premises. The lien shall further provide that when water and sewer service charges remain unpaid for sixty (60) days after they have been rendered, the lien thereby created may be foreclosed in the manner provided by any statute, law or city ordinance. 
E.  In the event of the payment of a water service deposit under subsection (D)(1) of this section, the deposit shall be refunded to the applicant upon the termination of water service and the determination that water and sewer charges have been paid in full to the city or, in the event that the applicant establishes a continuous payment record for water and sewer service charges with the city for a period of thirty-six (36) consecutive calendar months. 
F.  If an account for water service or sewer service becomes delinquent and the customer has paid a deposit under subsection (D)(1) of this section, the deposit may be applied to pay such delinquency and the city may take such other steps as are allowed by the provisions of this chapter to terminate service to the premises where the account is delinquent. 
G.  When water service is applied for, the city recorder, or his or her designee, shall provide the applicant with a copy of the notice of right to a meeting to discuss dispute as described in Section 13.04.060(B) of this chapter. 
H.  If a property owner has previously established a water account for a particular property and if water service is required for fewer than ten (10) days at that same property for the purpose of maintenance, the property owner or his authorized property manager may submit an application for temporary water service reconnection accompanied by a fee as established by resolution of the common council of Coquille that will entitle him to up to one thousand (1,000) gallons of water and automatic disconnection of service by city personnel on the tenth calendar day following connection. 
(Ord. 1402 § 3, 2000) 
(Ord. No. 1483, 11-7-2011) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1483, adopted Nov. 7, 2011, is effective Dec. 7, 2011. 
13.04.030 - Adjustment for leaks. 
    Where a leak exists underground between the meter and a building located either inside or outside of the city and the leak is repaired within ten (10) days after the owner, agent or occupant of the building becomes aware of such a leak, the water department may allow an adjustment of fifty (50) percent of the estimated excess water consumption. In any calendar year, the water department shall make no more than two leak adjustments for any unit as provided by this section. 
(Ord. 1402 § 4, 2000) 
13.04.040 - Private shut-off valve. 
    Whenever a new meter or service line is installed, a private shut-off valve shall be installed by the owner or customer. The shut-off valve shall be installed adjacent to and on the owner's or customer's side of a water meter. 
(Ord. 1402 § 5, 2000) 
13.04.050 - Use of fire hydrant. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate, alter, change, remove, disconnect, connect with, or interfere in any manner with, any fire hydrant owned or used by the city without first obtaining written permission from the water department. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the Coquille fire department. 
(Ord. 1402 § 6, 2000) 
13.04.060 - Meter reading and billing. 
A.  Effective December 2000, water bills will be prepared on a monthly basis. Water meters shall be read on or near the fifteenth (15th) day of each month. Water consumption, as indicated by the meter reading shall be rounded to a whole one thousand (1,000) gallons not larger than the indicated consumption. Water bills shall be mailed or delivered as soon after the date of meter reading as is conveniently possible. Water bills shall be due and payable on the date of mailing and shall be come delinquent on the fifteenth (15th) day of the month following the mailing, or the next business day; except in cases where special written contractual arrangements specify the monthly payment date. In accordance with the provisions of this section, service may be disconnected when the billing becomes delinquent. 
B.  A final hanger notice shall be placed at the customer's residence on the fifth (5th) day of the second month following the mailing of the bill, or the next business day. A final notice charge, which shall be established by resolution of the common council of the city, shall be assessed to the customer's account. The following notice regarding a right to a meeting will accompany the final hanger notice. 
NOTICE OF RIGHT TO A MEETING TO DISCUSS DISPUTE 
If you disagree with the proposed action to disconnect your water service for your delinquency because you believe that you do not owe this bill, that you have paid this bill, there is an error in the amount, that you did not receive this service or for any other reason, you may have a meeting with the city recorder to present your disagreement. Also, if any special medical conditions exist where discontinuing water service would significantly endanger your pre-existing health problem or a pre-existing health problem of a member of your household, and this is verified in writing from a licensed physician, you can request a meeting with the city recorder to discuss the proposed disconnection of water service. To request any meeting, you should call the city recorder or go to city hall in person as soon as possible, but in no case later than 5:00 p.m. of the payment due date as shown on the delinquent notice. 
The City of Coquille alone has the discretion whether to make payment arrangements with you. Your previous payment record, current amount owing or your ability to pay will be some of the criteria taken into consideration in determining whether to make payment arrangements with you. 
C.  If the city does not receive a request for a meeting with the city recorder after the final hanger notice has been placed at the customer's residence, the city may disconnect the water service after seven days. 
D.  Whenever disconnection is made for nonpayment of a water service bill, a re-connection charge, which shall be established by resolution of the common council of the City of Coquille, shall be paid before the customer's water service will be re-connected. 
E.  If the city receives a request for a meeting, either verbal or in writing, prior to the disconnection date specified in the disconnection notice, within five days of the date that the city recorder received the request for a meeting, the city recorder or his/her designee, shall set a date and time for the meeting. The city recorder shall provide the customer with written notice of the date, time and place that the meeting shall be held. 
F.  If the meeting with the customer is resolved in favor of the customer, the customer's water bill account shall be corrected and no disconnection of service shall be made. If the meeting with the customer is resolved in favor of the city, the customer shall immediately pay the amount of the delinquent billing or disconnection may occur immediately unless the customer appeals the city recorder's decision to the city council. 
G.  If the customer wishes to appeal the city recorder's decision to the city council, the customer shall deposit the amount of the disputed bill with the office of the city recorder immediately upon conclusion of the meeting. Deposit of the amount of the disputed bill will stay disconnection of the customer's water service until final resolution of the appeal to the city council. 
H.  The customer's appeal of the city recorder's decision shall be presented to the city council at its next regularly scheduled meeting, and the city council shall either deny the appeal, allow the appeal or adjust the bill to accurately reflect the customer's water service charges. Within two days, not including weekends or holidays, of the city recorder receiving a customer's request to appeal the city recorder's decision, the city recorder shall send to the customer, by regular mail, written notice of the date, time and place that the city council will consider the customer's appeal of the city recorder's decision regarding the customer's water bill. 
I.  If the customer paid the deposit to stay water service disconnection, and if upon the city council's final resolution of the customer's appeal of the city recorder's decision, an amount in excess of the amount determined as the correct water service charges exists, it shall be immediately refunded to the customer. 
J.  If the customer did not pay a deposit to stay water service disconnection, and water service was disconnected, and the customer's appeal to the city council is resolved in the customer's favor, the city shall not charge the customer a re-connection charge to re-connect the customer's water service. 
K.  If the city council denies the customer's appeal, and the customer paid the deposit to stay water service disconnection, the amount of the deposit shall be applied to pay the disputed water bill. On or after the date a water bill becomes delinquent; a disconnection notice shall be sent to the customer at the address on the city's records where the water bill was mailed. The notice shall state a date on which the water service will be disconnected if the delinquent account is not paid in full thereto, which date of disconnection shall be not sooner than five days after the date of mailing of the notice, not including weekends and holidays. The notice shall further provide that, if the customer disputes the correctness of the bill, that the customer may request an informal hearing with the city recorder or her designee by responding in writing to the city and by delivering written request to the offices of the city's water department the time provided for disconnection of service in the notice sent by the city and state specifically the nature of the dispute concerning the accuracy or correctness of the bill. 
L.  If the city does not receive a request for informal hearing by a customer disputing the correctness of the bill, the city may disconnect the water service to any customer having a delinquent bill after time specified in the final notice sent pursuant to subsection B of Section 13.04.060. Whenever disconnection is made for nonpayment of a bill, a charge to be established by resolution of the common council of Coquille shall be paid before reconnection is made to the customer, said charge being for the cost of reconnection. 
M.  There shall be a single rate or charge for water service, which shall be established by resolution of the common council of the city, and it shall apply to all units specified in Section 13.04.010, including, but not limited to, residential, apartments, multiple family dwellings and commercial users. The different rates are described as follows: 
1.  Basic Unit Service Charge. The first one thousand (1,000) gallons shown on the water meter for each building unit defined in Section 13.04.010. 
2.  Residential Rate. In addition to the basic unit service charge: each one thousand (1,000) gallons in excess of the first one thousand (1,000) gallons shown on the water meter shall be billed at a rate per thousand gallons. 
3.  Commercial Rate. This rate shall apply to all non-residential users. Users not receiving the sprinkling rate shall be charged based upon their total consumption. Charges shall be applied as follows: total consumption divided by the city's value of an EDU times the applicable base rate. Credit shall be given for each EDU base gallonage. Excess gallons beyond the amount credited in the EDU calculations shall be charged at the applicable excess gallonage rate. Commercial users who use less than or equal to the EDU gallonage per unit shall be charged the base rate per unit plus actual gallonage. 
4.  Meter Size Flat Rate Charges. Users utilizing meters in excess of three-quarters inch shall be assessed an additional flat rate as established by resolution of the common council of Coquille. 
5.  Standby Fire Line. Users utilizing standby fire lines shall be assessed a monthly capacity fee which shall be established by resolution of the common council of Coquille. 
(Ord. 1453, 2005) 
(Ord. No. 1491, 4-7-2014) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1491, adopted April 7, 2014, is effective May 2014. 
13.04.070 - Penalty for turning water on or off without authority. 
A.  Water shall not be turned on by any water consumer or other person without authority from the water department and, if the same is done, the water may then be shut off at the main or the meter removed, or both. The charge for shutting off the water at the main or for removing or replacing the meter shall be established by resolution of the common council of Coquille. All such charges shall be a lien against the premises where the water is supplied, and water shall not again be furnished to such premises until the charges are paid. It is an offense under the municipal code of the city for any person or persons to turn on the water via the water meter valve, or otherwise tamper with the water meter, without prior authority from the water department. 
B.  Water shall not be turned off by manipulation of the water meter valve by any water consumer or other person without authority from the water department, except in an emergency. Whether an emergency actually existed at the time the water was turned off shall be determined by the city. If water is turned off, or an attempt is made to turn the water off, charges for any resulting damage to the water meter valve, water meter, or water lateral shall be a lien against the premises where the water is supplied. Water shall not again be furnished to such premises until such charges are paid. It is an offense under the municipal code of the city of Coquille for any person or persons to turn off the water via the water meter valve without prior authority from the water department. 
(Ord. 1402 § 8, 2000) 
13.04.080 - Resale or distribution of water. 
    No water shall be resold or distributed by the recipient thereof from the city water supply to any other than those for which application has been made. A violation of this section shall be sufficient grounds for discontinuance of water service. 
(Ord. 1402 § 9, 2000) 
13.04.090 - Monthly water rates. 
    Water rates shall be established by resolution of the common council of Coquille. 
(Ord. 1402 § 10, 2000) 
13.04.100 - Private fire protection service. 
    Water service to private fire systems shall be at the rate established by the common council of Coquille, plus the cost of connecting the line to the city water system. 
(Ord. 1402 § 11, 2000) 
13.04.110 - Summer sprinkling rates. 
A.  The common council, in order to encourage residents to sprinkle lawns and yards during the summer season, may establish by resolution sprinkling water rates to carry out the intent of this section. 
1.  Such rates shall be effective for the mid-month readings of June through October. These residential sprinkling rates may only be provided under this section for water use in excess of the user's average consumption of the mid-month readings of November through May immediately prior to the effective date of the special sprinkling rates. 
2.  Sprinkling rates under the provisions of this section shall apply to residential customers inside the city boundaries. 
B.  The common council, in order to encourage commercial, nonresidential customers and high consumption residential users to maintain their lawns, gardens and landscaped areas during the summer season, may establish by resolution sprinkling water rates to carry out the intent of this section. 
1.  Commercial, residential and nonresidential customers inside the city boundaries shall be eligible for commercial or nonresidential sprinkling rates. To be eligible customers must have applied for, installed and paid for a separate water meter for sprinkling purposes. 
(Ord. 1445 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1444 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1433, 2001: Ord. 1432, 2001: Ord. 1422 § 1 (part), 2001: Ord. 1402 § 12, 2000) 
13.04.120 - Multiunits water meter. 
A.  Existing Multiunits on One Water Meter. When two or more units are served by a single water meter, the application for water service shall be in the landowner's name. A utility payment deposit shall be applied to each unit pursuant to Sections 13.04.010 and 13.04.020(D)(1) of this chapter. All landowners of multiunits existing on the date of adoption of the ordinance codified in this section shall be required to comply with this section or provide an individual meter to each unit, within one year of the date of adoption (February 28, 2000). 
B.  Future Multiunits. All units created after the adoption of the ordinance codified in this section shall have a separate water meter. 
(Ord. 1422 § 1 (part), 2001; Ord. 1402 § 13, 2000) 
13.04.130 - Water meter access-Landowner maintenance. 
    It is declared to be the policy of the city that the landowner to whom water service is being provided by the city shall bear the responsibility for maintaining water meter access in order to provide unrestricted access to the water meter which serves the landowner's property. Every landowner to whom water service is provided shall maintain water meter access so as to keep the water meter serving the landowner's property accessible. The landowner shall further be responsible for maintaining the vines, shrubs, trees, structures and any other obstacle growing on or over, built on or overhanging the meter or the area immediately surrounding the meter's location. 
(Ord. 1402 § 14, 2000) 
13.04.140 - Notice to landowner for water meter maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of the landowner to whom water service is being provided by the city to take whatever steps are necessary to provide water meter access in accordance with the provisions of Section 13.04.130 within ten (10) days of the date of a notice having been sent by the city to the landowner. The landowner's notice shall specify the action to be taken to provide adequate water meter access in compliance with Section 13.04.130. If, within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice, the landowner objects to the requirements set forth in the notice, the landowner may request a hearing to be held before the common council of the city by submitting a request for a hearing in writing to the city prior to the expiration of the ten (10) day period. The city shall set a date, time and place for the hearing on objections to the notice. The decision of the council on such hearing shall be final. Otherwise, if no request for hearing is made, the landowner shall comply with the requirements of the notice. 
(Ord. 1402 § 15, 2000) 
13.04.150 - Abatement by city. 
    If the landowner fails to comply with the requirements of the notice sent pursuant to Section 13.04.140 or fails to comply with the order of the common council following a hearing on request of the landowner, the city may perform the work necessary to comply with the notice and assess the cost of the work to the landowner. The work performed by the city may be done by the city crew or by subcontract or by any other method deemed appropriate by the city. If the cost of the work is not paid by the landowner within thirty (30) days following the date notice is sent to the landowner requesting payment, an assessment of the cost shall be made by resolution of the common council and shall be entered in the docket of city liens, and upon such entry being made, the amount shall constitute a lien upon the real property on which the work was performed. The lien may be enforced in the same manner as liens for street improvements are enforced and shall bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum. Such interest shall accrue from the date of the entry of the lien on the lien docket. An error in the name of the person in charge of the property shall not void the assessment. The assessment shall remain a valid lien against the property. 
(Ord. 1402 § 16, 2000) 
13.04.160 - A charge for water shutoff. 
    The city shall provide the service of water shutoff and restoration upon the request of a water service customer. A fee, established by resolution of the common council, shall be charged for this service. The fee shall be waived if, during the period when water is shut off, the customer shall install a turnoff valve in the water line on the customer's side and adjacent to the water meter. 
(Ord. 1402 § 17, 2000) 
13.04.170 - After hours service charge. 
    A water service customer shall be charged a fee, established by resolution of the common council, for any request for service from the city public works department if the request for service does not occur during the normal operating hours of the city public works department. This fee shall be charged to the water service customer on the next regular billing cycle following the date service is provided. 
(Ord. 1402 § 18, 2000) 
13.04.180 - Transferring of water accounts. 
    The city of Coquille with the adoption of the ordinance codified in this section established the following procedure for the transfer of water accounts: 
A.  The landlord/landlady or owner shall prepare a letter and post via certified mail, notifying the tenant of his or her intent to close the account of the property and provide five business days for the tenant to transfer the account. If the property is vacant, the landlord/landlady or owner shall provide a statement in writing to the city stating the property is vacant. 
B.  If the tenant fails to transfer the account into his or her name in the specified time, the landlord/landlady or owner shall provide to the city a copy of the notice and proof of delivery and a written request to the city to discontinue the service. 
C.  The city of Coquille shall notify the tenant with a copy of the disconnect request and a disconnect notice of at least five days. Twenty-four (24) hours before the shut-off, the city will hang a disconnect notice on the door. 
D.  If no arrangements to transfer the service have been made, the city will disconnect the water at the end of the specified period. 
(Ord. 1461 § 2, 2006) 
Chapter 13.08 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM 

13.08.010 - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, words shall mean as follows: 
    "Building drain" means that part of the piping which conveys sewage from within a building to the building sewer. 
    "Building sewer" means that part of the drainage system, which extends from the end of the building drain which is located five feet outside the building wall and conveys its discharge to that public sewer, private sewer, individual sewage disposal or other point of disposal. 
    "Commercial establishment" means any building or establishment or portion thereof engaging in any activity other than for residential purposes. Commercial does not include dwellings, residential courts, manufactured home park, or water districts. 
    "Convenience Store" means any retail grocery store that has some or all of the following characteristics: 
1.  Is under four thousand (4,000) square feet in area; 
2.  Requires a package liquor license; 
3.  Is open more than fifteen (15) hrs. a day; and 
4.  Has no public restrooms. 
    Dwelling, Manufactured Home. "Manufactured home dwelling" means any portable structure or vehicle which is constructed and designed to permit human occupancy thereof, and which is being used for residential purposes, including manufactured homes, mobile homes, and trailer houses. For the purpose of this definition, it shall be immaterial: 
1.  Whether the vehicle or structure is placed upon property for temporary, semi-permanent or permanent use; or 
2.  That the wheels may be removed allowing the vehicle or structure to be placed on posts, footing or a foundation. 
    Dwelling, Multiple. "Multiple dwelling" means a building designed and used for occupancy by three or more families, all living independently of each other and having separate housekeeping facilities for each family. This includes apartments, boarding houses and rooming houses. 
    Dwelling, Single-Family. "Single-family dwelling" means a building designed and used exclusively for the occupancy of one family and having housekeeping facilities for only one family. 
    Dwelling, Two-Family (Duplex). "Two-family (duplex) dwelling" means a building designed and used exclusively for the occupancy of two families living independently of each other and having housekeeping facilities for each family. 
    "EDU" means the city-wide average monthly winter water consumption for a single family residence based upon the months of November through April. 
    "Family" means one or more persons, excluding servants, related by blood, marriage or legal adoption or legal guardianship; a group of not more than five unrelated persons living together as a single nonprofit housekeeping unit and using common housekeeping facilities. 
    "Gravity system" means a sewer line installed on a grade that allows drainage or flow from the building sewer to the sewer main. 
    "Housekeeping facility" means a structure or portion thereof providing living, sleeping, sanitation and meal preparation facilities for one individual family. 
    "Landowner" means the person(s) in fee title to, or the contract purchaser of the real property, as evidenced by the Deed Records of Coos County, and shall not include a tenant or person having leasehold interest in the property. 
    "Manufactured home park" means any lot, tract or parcel of land under the same ownership where two or more, or a combination of two or more manufactured homes, mobilehomes, or trailer houses are used for human occupancy and are parked or sited within five hundred (500) feet of one another. 
    "Residence" means any dwelling. 
    "Residential court" means a group of two or more connected or unconnected residences erected on one parcel of land and designated primarily for transient or tourist rentals of less than one month. Includes "hotel" and "motel." 
    "Sewage ejector pump system" means a system utilizing advice for lifting sewage by entraining the sewage in a high-velocity jet of steam, air or water. 
    "Sewer lateral" means a sewer line between the public main sewer and the building sewer. 
    "STEF system" means septic tank effluent filter system which is an extension of a lateral to close proximity of the structure being served to include a septic tank, appurtenances and required sewer lines to allow gravity flow of filtered effluent to the trunk sewer. 
    "STEP system" means septic tank effluent pumped system is the extension of a lateral to close proximity of a structure being served and includes a septic tank, appurtenances and required sewer line to allow pressurized flow of effluent to the trunk sewer. 
    "Unit" means a structure, whether in whole or in part, in which a dwelling or commercial establishment exists. Units shall be calculated as follows: 
1. Single-family dwelling 1 unit 2. Two-family dwelling 2 units 3. Multiple dwelling 1 unit for each housekeeping facility 4. Manufactured home dwelling 1 unit 5. Manufactured home park 1 unit for each manufactured home, site or pad 6. Residential court 1 unit for each three rental units 7. Commercial establishment 1 unit for each separate business or occupant 8. Convenience store 1 unit maximum  
    "Unit service charge" means the service charge to each unit connected by single or multiple connections to a water meter. 
(Ord. 1446 § 2, 2003; Ord. 1443 §2, 2003; Ord. 1403 § 1, 2000) 
13.08.020 - Sewer connections. 
A.  No person, firm or corporation shall make any sewer connections with any part of the sanitary sewer or storm drain of the city without making application and security a permit. 
B.  It is unlawful to make alterations or repairs to or to install any new septic tank or drain field for purposes of sewage disposal on property where a city sewer exists in, on or across the property or in a street abutting such property, or where a city sewer which can be used exists within two hundred (200) feet of the building to be served and an assessment has been levied for such sewer service against such property, unless the alterations, repairs or installation are for a septic tank and/or appurtenances in connection with a STEF or STEP sewer system or sewage ejector pump system approved by the city and which is connected to the city's sewage disposal system. 
C.  Applicants for sewer connection permits must also conform with the provisions of any ordinances regulating and requiring permits for the making of cuts or excavations in or under streets or alleys. 
D.  Wherever there is now or may hereafter be constructed in any street or alley or section thereof a public sewer for the purposes of carrying sewage within the city, the owner or owners of the property abutting on, adjacent to or along the line of the sewer and within a distance of two hundred (200) feet thereof and having access to such sewer must connect the houses or buildings on such property with such sewer upon the order of the council. 
E.  Whenever the public works director, pursuant to an order of the council, shall notify in writing any owner or owners of property within the city to connect to a public sewer, it shall be the duty of such owner or owners to make application, file the plans therefor in the manner provided in this chapter, pay the fees as heretofore provided and complete said sewer connection within thirty (30) days from the date of notice, unless for good and sufficient reason the public works director, in writing, extends the time of the completion of such connection. 
F.  Application for connection permits to the city sewage disposal system shall be made in writing in a form prescribed by the public works director of the city and shall provide the following information: (1) the location of the property; (2) the number of buildings to be connected; (3) the name of the owner; (4) the name of the person or firm engaged to make the connection; (5) whether or not the real property to which the sewer connection is to be made has ever been in the past assessed for construction of a sewer to which the applicant desires to connect; (6) whether the system proposed to be installed will be a conventional gravity system, a STEF, STEP or sewage ejector pump system; and (7) such other information or plans as may be required by the public works director or this chapter. 
G.  No sewer connection permits shall be issued for property lying outside the existing limits of the city. 
(Ord. 1403 § 2, 2000) 
13.08.030 - Installation of STEF, STEP or sewage ejector pump system. 
A.  No application for installation of a STEF, STEP or sewage ejector pump system shall be allowed where the property is capable of direct connection to the city's sewer system by conventional gravity flow. The city, after considering future needs of the area, shall have discretion in deciding whether to approve a permit. 
B.  Ownership of Materials-Appurtenances STEF/STEP/Sewage Ejector Pump System: 
1.  The subject property owner shall be the owner of all material used in the installation of a STEF/STEP system from the point of the connection of the building sewer or building drain with the septic tank, to the city street right-of-way which shall include, but not be limited to, the following primary pieces of equipment and appurtenances: the septic tank or tanks, electrical panel, pump or filter and lateral line from tank to main sewer line. On and after the city's approval of the connection to the city's sewer system of a STEF/STEP system, the property owner shall be responsible for maintenance of all parts of the private system to, and including, the sewer connection. 
2.  The property owner shall be the owner of all material used in the installation of a sewage ejector pump system from the point of the connection of the building sewer or building drain with the septic tank to the city street right-of-way. The property owner shall be responsible for maintenance of all parts of the sewage ejector pump system from where the system connects to the property owner's building lateral to the city's main sewer line. 
C.  Inspection. Reasonable notice shall be given to the city's public works director to inspect all sewer connections before their completion and while the connections are still uncovered. All work shall be done according to the city's standard of specifications. Prior to approval of any STEF/STEP or sewer ejection pump system, the owner shall provide the city with a copy of the owner's plumbing permit for the installation of the system. 
D.  Specifications for construction of STEF/STEP or Sewer Ejector Pump System. 
1.  The city, by resolution, shall adopt such regulations as are necessary so as to provide detailed specifications for the manner of construction and installation of a STEF/STEP or sewage ejector pump system as permitted by this chapter. 
2.  In addition to the regulations adopted under subsection (D)(1) of this section and if the system is a sewage ejector pump system, installation shall be in conformance with the edition of the Oregon State Plumbing Code that is in effect at the time of such installation. 
E.  Property Owner's Continuing Obligations-STEP or Sewage Ejector Pump System. Upon approval of the installation of a STEP or sewage ejector pump system as provided herein, it shall be the continuing obligation of the property owner to provide, at the property owner's expense, continuous electrical service to the system so as to maintain it in continuous operation at all times while the system is connected to any building or structure. Upon the property owner's failure to comply with his or her obligation to provide continuous electrical service as required by this chapter and after notice of noncompliance by the city to the property owner and persons residing on the property, the city shall be authorized to disconnect any buildings located on the property from the city's water and sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. 1403 § 3, 2000) 
13.08.040 - Sewer application and inspection fees. 
A.  A sewer connection fee, established by resolution of the common council, shall be paid to the city at the time application is made for a connection permit. 
B.  If the application specifies installation of a STEF/STEP or Sewage Ejector Pump System, an additional inspection fee, established by resolution of the common council, shall be paid to the city at the time the application is made for a construction permit. 
C.  If the property for which the applicant desires a sewer connection has never been assessed for any portion of the costs of the sewer to which such applicant desires to make a connection, then in addition to the fees heretofore provided, the applicant shall pay an additional fee which shall be either the city's actual cost of extending the sewer, or the same assessment made in the adjoining sewer improvement district or to similarly situated property, whichever amount is greater, but in no event less than the minimum amount that the common council of the city sets by resolution for each building or residence to which the sewer connection is to be made. 
D.  Any payments made under this section shall not exempt the real property for which the application is made for connection from future assessments for costs of sewer improvements as may be made or assessed in future assessment proceedings. 
(Ord. 1403 § 4, 2000) 
13.08.050 - Construction sites. 
A.  All holders of building permits shall, on request by the building official of the city, provide information relating to sanitary sewage disposal during building construction at construction sites. 
B.  The city building official shall designate reasonable methods of sanitary sewage disposal at and near construction sites mentioned in this section and may, among other things, require the use of regular water closet toilet facilities, mechanized toilet facilities, the "sanican" type facility, or any other reasonable toilet facility, or may prohibit the use of such temporary toilet facility. In no case shall a pit toilet be approved. 
C.  In addition to designating the type of sanitary sewage disposal facility as provided in subsection B of this section, the building official may designate the place of use and location of such sanitary sewage disposal or toilet facility on such construction site and may, from time to time during such construction, required a change in the type of such facility and the location of the same on the construction site. Such location shall be at a place least likely to be offensive to adjoining properties and the view of the public. 
D.  Failure of the building permit holder to comply with the directions of the building official under the provisions of this chapter shall be cause to revoke such building permit. 
E.  No person, firm or corporation shall knowingly connect a pipe or drain or knowingly maintain a pipe or drain connection of roof water drainage, surface or subsurface water drainage, or storm water drainage to the sanitary sewage system of the city. 
(Ord. 1403 § 5, 2000) 
13.08.060 - Inspections. 
A.  Whenever an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this ordinance or whenever the building official, or his or her authorized representative as defined by the Uniform Building Code, has reasonable cause to believe that there exists on any premises any condition contrary to the requirements and provisions of this chapter, the building official, or his or her authorized representative, may enter onto such premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same and to perform a duty of determining whether or not the connection to the sanitary sewage system exists contrary to the requirements of this chapter; however, if such building is or such premises are occupied, the building official shall first present himself or herself and request entry. If such building is or such premises are unoccupied, the building official shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of the building or premises and request entry. If such entry is refused, the building official, or his or her authorized representative, shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
B.  No owner or occupant or any other person having charge, care or control of any building or premises shall fail or neglect, after proper demand is made as herein provided, to properly permit entry therein by the building official, or his or her authorized representative, for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. 1403 § 6, 2000) 
13.08.070 - Separation of storm and sanitary sewer. 
    Separation of storm sewers and sewers providing for the drainage of water, other than sanitary sewage, is necessary for the proper treatment and disposal of sanitary sewage by the city. Such separation has been required of the city as a condition of grant money to the city for the construction of sewage treatment facilities as required by the Department of Environmental Quality of the state of Oregon, and as required by the Environmental Protection Agency of the United States of America. Many private connections of storm water and surface and subsurface water to the sanitary sewers of the city exist and the city is engaging in a course of inspection and separation of such sewers and elimination of such drainage into the sanitary sewage system of the city. Such separation is essential for the proper treatment of sanitary sewage at the sewage treatment facility of the city. During the rainy season, sanitary sewage cannot be effectively treated at the plant, and, on many occasions, cannot be treated in any way whatsoever and the same is discharged into the Coquille River. 
(Ord. 1403 § 7, 2000) 
13.08.080 - Regulation of drainage. 
A.  Neither temporary nor permanent drainage of excavation into the sanitary sewer system shall be permitted. Drainage from roofs, storm sewers or storm drains shall not be permitted into the sanitary sewer system, and no such connection shall be permitted. 
B.  Sanitary Sewer Connection Repair Standard. 
1.  Any building sanitary sewer connected to the sewer system, whether within the city's right-of-way or within the bounds of the sewer user's property, which is determined by the city to be causing infiltration of surface, storm or groundwater into the sewer system, shall be repaired within sixty (60) days after the date of official notice to the legal property owner to do so. 
2.  All repairs shall be made at no cost to the city. 
C.  When repairs are made within the city right-of-way, repairs shall be under city specifications. 
D.  Before being covered, each repair must be inspected and approved by the city public works department. 
E.  If the repair corrections required by this section are not made, the city may enter the property and make them and cause the expenses to become a lien upon the property, which shall become due and payable upon entry in the lien docket. The city shall attempt to serve, by certified or registered mail, a written notice upon the owner of the property at the time the lien is entered on the city lien docket, which notice shall state the amount of the lien and give the property owner notice that the lien will be deemed delinquent if not paid within sixty (60) days after the date the lien was entered on the city lien docket. If the owner fails to pay the lien within sixty (60) days after entry of the lien on the lien docket, the city may enforce or foreclose the lien in the manner provided by law. 
F.  Right to Appeal. 
1.  Within thirty (30) days after the official notice, as provided in division B above, the person responsible may elect to file with the city recorder a written statement to protest the notice. 
2.  The statement shall be referred to the city council as a part of its regular agenda at its next succeeding meeting. At the time set for consideration of the appeal, the person protesting may appear and be heard by the council; and the council shall determine whether or not a cause of infiltration in fact exists; and the determination shall be entered in the official minutes of the council. Council determination shall be required only in those cases where a written statement has been filed as provided. 
3.  If the council determines that a cause of infiltration does in fact exist, the person responsible shall, within thirty (30) days after the council determination, make all necessary repairs to eliminate the cause of infiltration. 
G.  Notwithstanding division A above, the city is authorized to take immediate abatement action in the event of an emergency that creates an unreasonable risk to the public health or safety. The city shall make a reasonable attempt to notify the person in charge of or using the property, and the owner if that is a different person, prior to the city's entering the property to make the repairs. The city may cause the expenses to become a lien on the property in the manner provided herein. 
(Ord. 1403 § 8, 2000) 
(Ord. No. 1493 B, Art. 1, 4-6-2015) 
13.08.090 - Deposits in sewers. 
A.  The following shall not be allowed to flow into or be deposited in the sewer system: 
1.  Petroleum, coal tar, vegetable and mineral oils and products and their derivatives and waste; 
2.  Greases, oils and sludge from service stations, garages, repair shops, machine shops, car wastes, cleaning establishments or other industries or establishments; 
3.  Explosives or inflammable liquids and gases; 
4.  Acids, alkalis or other corrosive liquids, gases or substances of sufficient strength to damage sewers, manholes, pumping stations or treatment plant units; 
5.  Paints or waste products from paint manufacture; 
6.  Substances which will form deposits or obstructions in sewers or which when mixed with sewage will precipitate material and thus form deposits in sewers; 
7.  Ashes, cinders, sand, earth, coal, rubbish or metals of any kind; 
8.  Live steam, exhaust steam or water having a temperature above one hundred forty (140) degrees Fahrenheit; 
9.  Ground or unground fruit peelings and cores from canneries or packing plants; 
10.  Cull fruits and vegetables; 
11.  Fruit and vegetable pits and seeds such as those from peaches, apricots, cherries, prunes, pumpkins and squash; 
12.  Paunch, stable and barn manure; 
13.  Cull walnuts and filberts; 
14.  Offal from slaughterhouses; 
15.  Dead animals; 
16.  Sulfite liquor and "white" water from pulp and paper mills. 
17.  Stormwater. 
B.  Grease Traps. Garages, services stations, restaurants, car washes and wash racks of any kind shall be equipped with suitable grease traps approved by the plumbing inspector before the same can be connected to the sanitary sewer system. Such grease traps shall be maintained by the operator of any such establishment in such manner as to prevent such grease, oil and sludge from entering the city sanitary sewer system. 
(Ord. 1403 § 9, 2000) 
(Ord. No. 1493 B, Art. 2, 4-6-2015) 
13.08.100 - Sewer rate charges. 
A.  The city imposes a monthly sewer use charge for each building unit as specified in Section 13.08.010. Any building unit within two hundred (200) feet of an available sewer line shall pay the monthly rate herein specified even through the building unit is not connected to the city sewer system. The intent of this chapter is to establish uniform rates for all water users within the city who discharge water, sewage or anything else into the city sewer system. 
B.  There shall be a single rate or charge for sewer service, which shall be established by resolution of the common council of the city, and it shall apply to all units specified in Section 13.08.010, including, but not limited to, residential, apartments, multiple family dwellings and commercial users. The different rates are described as follows: 
1.  Basic Unit Service Charge. The first one thousand (1,000) gallons shown on the water meter for each building unit defined in Section 13.08.010. 
2.  Residential Rate. In addition to the basic unit service charge: each one thousand (1,000) gallons in excess of the first one thousand (1,000) gallons shown on the water meter shall be billed at a rate per thousand gallons. 
3.  Commercial Rate. This rate shall apply to all non residential users. Users shall be charged based upon their total consumption. Charges shall be applied as follows: total consumption divided by the city's value of an EDU times the applicable base rate. Credit shall be given for each EDU base gallonage. Excess gallons beyond the amount credited in the EDU calculations shall be charged at the applicable excess gallonage rate. Commercial users who use less than or equal to the EDU gallonage per unit shall be charged the base rate per unit plus actual gallonage. 
4.  Special Maintenance Charge. In addition to the rate charges specified in subsection B of this section, any building connected to the city's sanitary sewer system which utilizes a STEF or STEP sewage disposal system shall pay a monthly maintenance charge to be established by the common council. 
5.  High Strength. For users which generate a high BOD content of wastewater, the user shall, in addition to their consumption charge, be assessed a ten percent (10%) high strength surcharge on their total bill. For the purposes of this section high strength users include, but are not limited to, restaurants, Coos County Jail, commercial kitchens and schools which prepare hot meals. 
6.  Tolling of Additional Consumption Charges. During the months in which sprinkling rates are in effect, sewer charges for users shall be based upon the average winter usage. Users which have both a regular water meter and separate sprinkling meter shall be charged for actual consumption regardless of average winter usage. 
(Ord. 1499 § 2, 2004; Ord. 1443 § 3, 2003; Ord. 1403 § 10, 2000) 
13.08.110 - Violations-Penalties. 
    A violation of this chapter is punishable, upon conviction, by a fine to be established by resolution of the common council of the city. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense hereunder. 
(Ord. 1403 § 11, 2000) 
Chapter 13.12 - WATER SERVICE EXTENSIONS 

13.12.010 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to specify terms and conditions upon which the facilities of the city's water service may be extended to any premises when the premises are not adjacent to or presently capable of connection directly to a city water main. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19 (part), 2000) 
13.12.020 - Within the corporate boundaries of the city. 
A.  Expenses for Water Main Extensions. 
1.  Any person or persons desiring to extend a city water main line to their property for connection thereto, shall be responsible for the payment of costs for engineering, inspection, testing and construction of the city water main line according to the requirements of this chapter and Chapter 13.04 and to standard specifications and drawings submitted to and approved by the city public works director. 
2.  All such water main line extensions, water laterals and meters, not including water service lines, shall become the property of the city upon completion of the same by the owner or contractor and upon inspection and acceptance by the city. The person(s) constructing the water main line extensions, water laterals and meters, shall provide and dedicate to the city an easement of a width and length required by the city for maintenance and operation of the city water system prior to acceptance of the same by the city. The owner or contractor shall provide to the city not less than a one year warranty on materials and construction. 
3.  If the water main line extension, as provided for herein, provides water service, or is capable of providing water service, to premises other than those owned by the person(s) extending the water main line, and such other premises are not connected to the city water system, then the person(s) constructing the water main line extension shall file a verified statement of the total cost of construction of the water main line extension with the city recorder. The city recorder, after verifying the statement of costs, shall compute a just and reasonable method of apportionment of the costs for each premises capable of being served by the water main line. 
4.  After the city recorder computes the proportionate costs attributable to each premises, the city recorder shall maintain a statement showing the costs of construction attributable to each property owner who did not share in the initial cost of construction of the water main line. 
5.  Any property owner who did not share in the initial cost of construction of a water main line who desires to connect to the water main line extended as provided for herein, shall first be required to pay the computed proportionate amount described in subsection (A)(3) of this section to the city recorder, together with interest at the statutory rate per annum before connection shall be allowed to the water main line. Upon receipt of the payment, as provided for herein, the city recorder shall attach to the original computation of proportionate costs a statement, duly certified, showing that payment of water main line construction charges attributable to the property owner seeking connection has been made. 
6.  Upon receipt of the payment attributable to the property owner seeking connection to the water main line extension as provided for herein, together with the interest payment, the city recorder shall refund the same to the person(s) who initially paid for the water main line extension such amount(s) that the person(s) are respectively entitled. In the event the person(s) who initially paid for the water main line extension shall have transferred the premises to a third person by contract of sale, the city recorder shall pay such proportionate share to a purchaser under contract of sale if in such contract of sale, the seller authorizes such payment to be made to the purchaser. After the period of ten (10) years has expired, the city shall not require any person(s) who desire connect to the water main line to pay the proportionate share of construction costs as set forth in this section, nor shall the city be responsible for the collection of the same. 
B.  Location and Ownership of Water Main Lines. 
1.  The city will allow water main line extensions, water laterals and meters only on rights-of-way, easements or publicly owned property. Easements secured for water main extensions shall be in the name of the city or transferred to the city, along with all rights and title to the water main line, at the time the service is provided to the customer(s) paying for the extension. 
2.  The property owner shall install and maintain, at the owner's expense, the water service line from the owner's water meter to the owner's premises. The city shall be the owner of all water service lines from the connection to the water main line to the city's water meter. The city shall be the owner of all water meters connected to the city's water line. 
3.  A water main extension, water lateral and meter shall become the property of the city at the time of installation. The city council, or its designee, shall determine the size of water main line extensions and all extensions shall be made only with prior approval by the city. All installation procedures and materials for installation of city water lines shall be in accordance with city and state of Oregon standards. 
4.  At the time of the city's acceptance of a water main line extension, as provided in this chapter, the city shall assume responsibility for maintenance of the system accepted. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(a)-(c), 2000) 
13.12.030 - Outside the corporate boundaries of the city. 
A.  Approval of Extension. The city shall not give approval to extend water service to premises located outside the city's approved urban growth boundary unless such approval is for one of the following: 
1.  Development of designated commercial or industrial sites; 
2.  Development of "recreational" planned unit developments (PUD's); 
3.  Curing documented health hazards; 
4.  Providing water service to existing rural-residential areas or to other areas committed to nonresource use upon a finding that Goal 14 Standards have been met; or 
5.  Publicly owned parks. 
B.  In addition to the other requirements provided by this chapter and Chapter 13.04, water service shall not be extended to premises situated outside the city's approved urban growth boundary except upon the city council's written resolution containing specific findings of the following: 
1.  That the services and facilities are extended solely for the purposes expressed in subsection A of this section and not for the purpose (express or implied) of justifying further expansion into rural areas; 
2.  Identifying the specific provision of subsection A of this section justifying the proposed extension; 
3.  That the area where the service is proposed to be extended is capable of being fully served by the city; and 
4.  That hook-up of city water lines to resource lands will be prohibited unless specifically allowed under subsection A of this section. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(d), 2000) 
13.12.040 - Location of extension. 
A.  Extension of Water Service to Premises with Frontage on Public Main. Water service may be extended to premises outside of the city limits only when those premises have frontage on a public main that has been built to current city standards to serve the premises requesting service and such main is constructed and extended so as to provide service to adjacent premises and has been dedicated to and accepted by the city, together with all necessary easements and rights-of-way therefor, all in conformance with the requirements of this and any other relevant city ordinance. The city council may extend such service only after proper application as required by this chapter. 
B.  Extension of Water Service to Contiguous Premises. If the city receives a request for extension of water service to premises outside of the corporate boundaries of the city, and the subject premises are contiguous to, and capable of immediate annexation to, the city, water service shall not be extended to such premises unless the property owner consents to annexation and petitions the city for such annexation. If the subject premises is contiguous to the city but outside of the city's approved urban growth boundary, the city may delay action on an application for extension of water service pending approval of a request for expansion of the city's urban growth boundary for purposes of annexation of the property proposed to be served by the city's water system. 
C.  Extension of Water Service to Noncontiguous Premises. If the city receives a request for extension of water service to premises outside of the corporate boundaries of the city and the premises are contiguous to the city and also not capable of immediate annexation as provided in subsection B of this section, but the property is within the city's approved urban growth boundary, no approval shall be granted under the provisions of this chapter for extension of water service to the subject premises until the property owner and the city have executed an agreement wherein the parties agree to annex the subject premises to the city at such future time as annexation is legally possible. The city has the discretion to determine the timing for the future annexation. The parties' agreement shall include a provision that the agreement and covenant to annex the subject premises shall be a covenant to run with the subject premises. Additionally, the agreement shall provide that the agreement be recorded in the records of Coos County, Oregon; and, the property owner shall be responsible for all recordings costs. 
D.  The city shall only allow water main extension, laterals and meters to be located on public rights-of-way, easements granted to the city, or publicly owned property. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(e), 2000) 
13.12.050 - Water main extension expenses. 
A.  Any person or person desiring to extend a city water main, water lateral and meter under the provisions of this chapter to their property for connection thereto shall be responsible for the payment of costs for engineering, inspection, testing and construction of the same according to the requirements of this chapter and Chapter 13.04 and to standard specifications and drawings submitted to and approved by the city public works director. 
B.  All such water main line extensions, water laterals and meters not including water service lines, shall become the property of the city upon completion of the same by the owner or contractor and upon completion of the same by the owner or contractor and inspection and acceptance by the city. The person or persons constructing the water main line extensions, water laterals and meters shall provide and dedicate to the city an easement of a width and length required by the city for maintenance and operation of the city water system prior to acceptance of the same by the city. The owner or contractor shall provide to the city not less than a one year warranty on all materials and construction. 
C.  If the water main line, as extended as provided for herein, provides water service or is capable of providing water service to property other than the property owned by the person extending the water service, which property is not previously connected with the city water system, then the person or persons constructing the water main line extension shall file a verified statement of the total cost of construction of the water main line with the city recorder. The city recorder, after verifying the statement of costs, shall compute a just and reasonable method of apportionment of the costs for each property capable of being served by the water main line. 
D.  After computation of the proportionate costs attributable to each property by the city recorder, the city recorder shall maintain a statement showing the costs of construction attributable to each property. The city recorder shall then maintain a certified list of the costs attributable to each property owner who did not share in the cost of construction of the water main line in the first instance. 
E.  Any person or persons owning property who did not share in the initial cost of construction of a water main line who desire to connect to the water main line extended as provided for herein shall first be required to pay to the city recorder the proportionate amount as computed by the city recorder in subsection C of this section together with interest at the statutory rate per annum before connection shall be allowed provided for herein, the city recorder shall attach to the original computation of proportionate costs a statement, duly certified, showing that payment of water main line construction charges attributable to the property seeking connection have been paid. 
F.  Upon receipt of the payment attributable to property seeking connection to the water main line extension as provided for herein, together with the interest payment, the city recorder shall refund the same to the person or persons originally paying for the water main line extension in an amount to which said person or persons are respectively entitled. In the event the person or persons originally paying for the water main line extension shall have transferred the property to a third person, the city recorder shall pay such proportionate share to a purchaser under contract of sale, if in such contract of sale the seller authorizes such payment to be made to the purchaser. After the period or ten (10) years has expired, the city shall not require any person or persons desiring to connect to the water main line to pay the proportionate share of construction costs as set forth in this section, nor shall the city be responsible for the collection of the same. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(f), 2000) 
13.12.060 - Potential water service disconnection. 
    All service provided to properties located outside the corporate boundaries of the city shall be subject to disconnection in the event of shortage of water supply within the city. Pressure and other conditions in all water service provided outside the city shall be at the risk of the purchaser of water, without guarantee or warranty by the city. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(g), 2000) 
13.12.070 - Ownership of extension. 
A.  Extension With Master Meter. Prior to extending a water main beyond the corporate boundaries, the city may require that a master meter be installed inside the corporate boundaries for an extension to be located outside the corporate boundaries. If a master meter is required by the city, the city will not assume ownership of the extension, except for the individual property water meters. 
B.  Extension Without Master Meter. Water main extensions, water laterals and meters outside the corporate boundary and without a required master meter shall become the ownership of the city. 
C.  The property owner(s) served by an extension shall be responsible for all costs associated with an extension. All installation procedures and materials for installation of water lines shall be in accordance with city and state of Oregon standards. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(h), 2000) 
13.12.080 - Maintenance of water extension. 
    If a master meter is required, maintenance of water main lines, water laterals, and all appurtenances of the extension, except for water meters, of the extension located outside the city, shall be the responsibility of the water users of the line until such time as the property adjacent to the water main line has been annexed to the city. At the time of annexation of the property adjacent to a main line, the city shall only assume responsibility for the maintenance at the main line, water laterals and meters if the main line and laterals were installed to city specifications. 
(Ord. 1402 § 19(i), 2000) 
Chapter 13.16 - CROSS CONNECTIONS 

13.16.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. If a word or term used in this chapter is not contained in the following list, its definition, or other technical terms used, shall have the meanings or definitions listed in the most recent edition of the Manual of Cross Connection Control published by the Foundation for Cross Connection Control and Hydraulic Research, University of Southern California. 
    "Approved backflow prevention assembly" or "backflow assembly" or "assembly" means an assembly to counteract backpressure or prevent backsiphonage. This assembly must appear on the list of approved assemblies issued by the Oregon Health Division. 
1.  "Reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly" or "reduced pressure principle assembly" or "RP assembly" or "RP" means an assembly containing two independently acting approved check valves together with a hydraulically-operated, mechanically independent pressure differential relief valve located between the check valves and at the same time below the first check valve. The assembly shall include properly located test cocks and tightly closing shut-off valves at the end of the assembly. 
2.  "Double check valve backflow prevention assembly" or "double check assembly" or "double check" or "DC" means an assembly which consists of two independently operating check valves which are spring-loaded or weighted. The assembly comes complete with a gate valve on each side of the checks, as well as test cocks to test the checks for tightness. 
3.  "Pressure vacuum breaker backflow prevention assembly" or "pressure vacuum breaker" or "PVB" means an assembly which provides protection against backsiphonage, but does not provide adequate protection against backpressure backflow. The assembly is a combination of a single check valve with an AVB and can be used with downstream shutoff valves. In addition, the assembly has suction and discharge gate valves and test cocks which allows the full testing of the assembly. 
    "Air gap" means a physical separation between the free flowing discharge end of a potable water supply piping and/or appurtenance and an open or nonpressure receiving vessel, plumbing fixture or other device. An "approved air-gap separation" shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe measured vertically above the overflow rim of the vessel, plumbing fixture or other device; in no case less than one inch. 
    "Atmospheric vacuum breaker backflow prevention device" or "atmospheric vacuum breaker" or "AVB" means a device that cannot be tested and cannot prevent backpressure backflow, but is used to prevent backsiphonage in non-health hazard conditions. 
    "Auxiliary supply" means any water source or system other than the public water system, that may be available in the building or on the property. 
    "Backflow" means the flow in the direction opposite to the normal flow or the introduction of any foreign liquids, gases or substances into the water system of city. 
    "Backpressure" means any elevation of pressure in the downstream piping system (by any means) above the supply pressure at the point of consideration which would cause, or tend to cause, a reversal of the normal direction of flow and the introduction of fluids, mixtures or substances from any source other than the intended source. 
    "Backsiphonage" means the flow of water or other liquids, mixture or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than its intended source caused by a sudden reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system. 
    "Boresight" or "boresight to daylight" means providing adequate drainage for backflow prevention assemblies installed in vaults through the use of an unobstructed drain pipe. 
    "Contamination" means the entry into or presence in a public water supply system of any substance which may be deleterious to health and/or quality of the water. 
    "Coquille" means city of Coquille. 
    "Cross connection" means any physical arrangement where a potable water supply is connected, directly or indirectly (actual or potential), with any other nondrinkable water system, used water system or auxiliary water supply, sewer, drain conduit, swimming pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, swamp coolers, air conditioner units, fire protection system, or any other assembly which contains, or may contain, contaminated water, sewage or other liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water system as a result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or change over assemblies, or other temporary or permanent assemblies through which, or because of which, backflow may occur are considered to be cross connections. 
    "Degree of hazard" means the low or high hazard classification that shall be attached to all actual or potential cross connections. 
1.  "High hazard" means the classification assigned to an actual or potential cross connection that potentially could allow a substance that may cause illness or death to backflow into the potable water supply. 
2.  "Low hazard" means the classification assigned to an actual or potential cross connections that potentially could allow a substance that may be objectionable but not hazardous to one's health to backflow into the potable water supply. 
3.  "Health hazard" means an actual or potential threat of contamination of a physical or toxic nature to the public potable water system or the consumer's potable water system that would be a danger to health. 
4.  "Plumbing hazard" means an internal or plumbing-type cross connection in a consumer's potable water system than may be either a pollutional or a contamination-type hazard. 
5.  "Pollutional hazard" means an actual or potential threat to the physical properties of the water system or the potability of the public or the consumer's potable water system but which would not constitute a health or system hazard, as defined. The maximum degree of intensity of pollution to which the potable water system could be degraded under this definition would cause a nuisance or be aesthetically objectionable or could cause minor damage to the system or its appurtenances. 
6.  "System hazard" means an actual or potential threat of severe danger to the physical properties of the public or consumer's potable water supply or of a pollution or contamination that would have a detrimental effect on the quality of the potable water in the system. 
    "Division" means Oregon Health Division. 
    "Point-of-use isolation" means the appropriate backflow prevention within the consumer's water system at the point at which the actual or potential cross connection exists. 
    "Potable water supply" means any water supply intended or used for human consumption or other domestic use. 
    "Premises" means any piece of property to which water is provided, including all improvements, mobile structures, and structures located on it. 
    "Premises isolation" means the appropriate backflow prevention at the service connection between the public water system and the water user. 
    "Public water system" or "system" means any public or privately owned water system which supplies water for public domestic use. The system must meet all the health requirements set forth by the Oregon Health Division. The system will include all services, reservoirs, facilities, and any equipment used in the process of producing, treating, storing or conveying water for public consumption. 
    "Representative of the water system" means a person designated by the city to perform cross connection control duties that shall include, but are not limited to, cross connection inspections and water use surveys. 
    "Service connection" is the point of delivery at which the water purveyor loses control of the water. 
    "Tester" means a person that is a certified backflow prevention assembly technician approved by and registered with the Oregon Health Division. 
    "Thermal expansion" means heated water that does not have the space to expand. 
(Ord. 1399 § 1.01, 2000) 
13.16.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to protect the water supply of the city from contamination or pollution due to any existing or potential cross connections. 
(Ord. 1399 § 1.02, 2000) 
13.16.030 - Backflow prevention assembly requirements. 
    A representative of the water system of city shall determine the type and location of any backflow assembly to be installed within the area served by Coquille. An assembly will be required in each of the following circumstances, but the representative is in no way limited to the following circumstances: 
A.  The nature and extent of any activity of the premises, or the materials used in connection with any activity of the premises, or materials stored on the premises, could contaminate or pollute the potable water supply. 
B.  Premises having any one or more cross connections as that term is defined in this Section 13.16.010, are identified or are present.
